    Recipe for a Healing Powder

    Two and a half qian of wood fragrance, separately ground frankincense, and myrrh, each one qian. Two pieces of nutmeg, wrapped and cooked. The right side is to be powdered. For each dose, take one qian, with one large dry jujube, pitted. First, put half the medicine inside the jujube, then soak half a grain of croton seed in water, followed by adding half a qian of powdered medicine. Form into a cake wrapped in oil dough, about a finger thick. Cook over fire until the dough is done, then remove the dough and discard the croton seed, chewing the medicine finely, with rice drink, taken on an empty stomach.

    An alternative method uses one tael of powdered frankincense and two taels of processed nutmeg ball, combined with aged rice paste to make pills.

    True Formula of Divine Powder treats men and women suffering from dampness affecting the spleen and stomach, with cold settling in the middle, frequent injury from eating, fullness and heaviness in the chest, swelling in the sides, gurgling intestines, tightness and pain in the lower abdomen, urgency below the navel, irregular bowel movements, sluggish digestion of grains, feelings of urgency and heaviness, diarrhea with pus and blood, or with five colors, or resembling fish eyes, or bean juice, or fresh blood, or resembling rotten meat, often without restraint, enduring for a long time, lethargy, weakness, heavy limbs, and fluctuating chills and fevers. This medicine can strengthen and nourish the spleen and stomach, warm the center, and alleviate abdominal pain; its use brings significant benefits.

    Ingredients:

    • Haritaki peel
    • Dried ginger, roasted
    • Cloves
    • Nutmeg, wrapped and cooked
    • Scomber fish bones, skinned
    • Red stone resin
    • Licorice, roasted to yellow, each one tael
    • Five liang of millet husks, crushed and vinegar-fried

    The right side is to be finely powdered. For each dose, first take one cup of water, add a little frankincense, boil for five to seven minutes, then mix in two qian of the powdered medicine, and take it warm before meals.[170p]
    (Grass and tongue) Loosened seeds: Treats prolonged cases of five-colored dysentery that won’t heal. Hu Daqing had a servant suffering from dysentery for two years and, upon meeting a Daoist in Hangzhou, was cured using this formula.

Take one pill per year, ten pills at ten years, following the age for consumption without strict timing, swallowed with rice drink.

      Yangzi's Method for Complete Protection of Life

    For the initial treatment of dysentery, if there is first the onset of chills and fever with a headache, and blood changes in the middle leading to frequent bouts of red dysentery, the following formula is prescribed:

    • Xi Xin (Asarum) 8 drachmas
    • Qian Niu (Wrapped in cloth, baked until cooked) 4 drachmas
    • Ma Huang (Ephedra) 3 parts
    • Guan Gui (Cinnamon twig) 3 parts
    • Xiong Dan (Sichuan lovage) 2 taels
    • Bai Zhu (Atractylodes) 2 taels
    • Gao Ben (Ligusticum) 5 qian
    • Du Huo (Angelica) 5 qian
    • Jie Geng (Platycodon) 5 qian
    • Fang Feng (Siler) 5 qian
    • Bai Shao (White peony) 5 qian
    • Bai Zhi (Angelica dahurica) 5 qian
    • Dan Pi (Moutan) 1 part
    • Gan Cao (Licorice) 1 part

    Machinate these into a fine powder. Every dose is 2 qian, taken with warm soup prepared outside of meal times, and consume alongside the dregs to counteract heat. If, after two or three doses, the chills and fever persist, the subsequent prescription should be used.

    Huan Zhen Powder

    For the treatment of toxic dysentery when first onset includes chills and fever, take the previously mentioned formula. Once the chills and fever have subdued and the red dysentery has decreased, then this Huan Zhen Powder should be introduced. However, if the chills and fever do not recede and the red dysentery continues, do not take this medicine.

    Five He Zi (Terminalia) should be wrapped in flour and baked until cooked; they should not be raw or burnt. Remove the flour and while still hot, bite through the He Zi, discarding the pit but retaining the skin and drying it out.

    Crush and sieve into a fine powder. For each dose, take 2 qian and mix it with 1.5 bowls of rice soup, reducing it to 1 bowl. Consume on an empty stomach with the dregs. If one expectorates a bit of saliva, that is even better. After taking several doses, the large intestine will gradually calm down, and upon evacuation, reduce further consumption. Follow up with the third medicinal approach to consolidate the large intestine. If the previous medicine has not reduced the intense heat and bloody dysentery, do not take this medicine.[174p]

    An He Yin Zi treats both red and white dysentery, regardless of age. Use 2.5 qian each of poppy husk and wood fragrance, and 1 qian each of roasted licorice and ground earth elm. Grind these into a fine powder. The dosage is 3 qian per serving, mixed with rice drink to be taken.

    Yu Bao Du treats all forms of deficiency-cold dysentery, red or white, as well as abdominal pain, loose intestines, and extreme cold in the stomach. For this, use 4 liang of qian sha, stir-fried, 5 qian of white alum, and 1 liang of official cinnamon. Grind these into a powder, mix them uniformly to form a pouch, and dissolve in cold water. Apply the paste on the skin over the abdomen, and secure it with cloth. If feeling very hot, cover it with clothing. When the medicine dries, rewet it to maintain warmth. This can be used three to four times.

    Ruan Hong Wan eliminates deficiency and accumulations, and treats imbalanced heat and cold, as well as red and white dysentery mixed with pus and blood. Separate grind 1 piece of frankincense the size of a jujube, 1 piece of myrrh the same size, 2 scorpions (remove toxins), 49 pieces of Siao Sui Zi (remove skins), along with powdered frost and yellow lead separately ground. Use 5 qian each of yellow wax, and 1 qian of red cinnabar, all ground separately. Remove the skins from 20 pieces of wild castor seeds, but do not remove the oil, and grind into a paste. Mix these powders uniformly, melt the wax in ceramic until it becomes fluid, then add about half a teaspoon of sesame oil, and finally mix in the medicine to form pills the size of mung beans, reserving half of the red cinnabar for the coating. The dosage for adults is 20 pills, taken with frankincense decoction. For children, make the pills the size of yellow millet, taking one pill each time with frankincense decoction before meals.[178p]
    Cinnamon Pill: Treats white dysentery and abdominal pain.
    Wrap and cook some nutmeg, wrap and cook some cardamom, crushed sand ginger, and the hairless tips of loquat leaves, each weighing one tael; two taels of earth rhubarb; five qian each of costus, agarwood, and ground Beijing ink.
    Make a fine powder, mix with millet rice to form pills the size of cherries. Take two pills before meals, dissolved in rice drink.

    Mica Powder: Treats chronic dysentery that does not heal over the years.
    Mix three fen each of mica powder, white poria, and processed aconite (removing skin and navel); half a tael each of red stone resin and dragon bone.
    Make a fine powder, take two qian before meals, mixed with warm wine or rice drink; also treats bloody dysentery.

    Golden Star Eel Powder: Treats chronic dysentery.
    Use five taels each of golden star eel, vinegar-fried alum, and lead oxide.[179p]
    The following are powdered remedies. Take two qian before meals, mixed with rice wine.

    Wu Ti Pill: Treats chronic dysentery that does not heal, along with worms and rectal prolapse.
    Ingredients: Stir-fried Wu Ti, Huanglian (with beards removed), each two liang; Snake bile five qian.
    Grind to a fine powder, mix with honey to form pills the size of Paeonia seeds. Take thirty pills before meals, washed down with apricot kernel soup.

    Xiang Su San: Treats chronic new dysentery.
    Ingredients: Stir-fried poppy husk, two liang; Mu Xiang, Di Yu, Chen Pi (retain the white part), stir-fried dried ginger, honey-fried licorice, each five qian.
    Grind to a coarse powder, take three qian, with one and a half cups of water and one date, boil until reduced to one cup, strain, and drink warm before meals.

    Wu Qi Decoction: Treats chronic dysentery, regardless of whether it's red or white, it treats both.
    Ingredients: Two He Zi—one raw and one roasted in flour, pit removed; nutmeg and cardamom, each two, prepared as above; Mu Xiang, the size of a jujube; licorice one inch long, roughly the size of a finger, roasted until red.
    Grind to a fine powder, take two qian at any time, using rice wine to wash it down.

    Mai Mian Pill: Treats resting dysentery where one cannot eat or drink and suffers from emaciation.
    Ingredients: Stir-fried barley flour, Fu Zi, roasted, peeled and split; white Poria, Guang Gui, stir-fried Chen Qu, stir-fried Wu Mei meat, ginseng, each one liang.
    Grind to a fine powder, mix with honey to form pills the size of Paeonia seeds. Take thirty pills, boiled with jujube meat soup, at any time. There is also a method for making batch dough pills on the seventh day of the seventh month.[180p]
    Fu Ling Decoction: For the treatment of generalized edema after dysentery.
    Ingredients: Red Fu Ling, fried Bai Zhu, lightly fried Ze Qi Ye, each one tael; Fang Ji, roasted white root of mulberry, Huang Qin, She Gan, and Ze Xie, each three taels.
    Preparation: Grind the above. Each dose is five qian (money), first boil three cups of water with one half cup of soybeans, reduce to two cups, strain, add the herbs, and boil down to one cup. Divide into two doses. If not healed, take frequently.

    Xiao Pi Wan: For the treatment of fullness and bloating in the abdomen after dysentery.
    Ingredients: Aged tangerine peel, white removed; green tangerine peel, white removed, both one tael; Mu Xiang two qian; Cang Zhu soaked and roasted, four taels.
    Preparation: Grind into powder, make into pills the size of a phoenix seed with vinegar. Each dose is twenty pills, taken on an empty stomach with warm wine. For children, three to seven pills with rice soup.

    Zhu Gan Wan: For the treatment of weak spleen and stomach after dysentery, with loss of appetite and weak limbs.
    Ingredients: One large leaf of pig liver, boiled with vinegar until soft and ground into a paste; lightly fried Wu Mei; dry ginger roasted; grass cardamom seeds; lightly fried Dang Gui; nutmeg; thick skin with ginger juice roasted; Keli fruit stewed; and Piper vine seeds, each one tael; and one part of licorice, lightly roasted; and five qian of cinnamon heart.
    Preparation: Grind into powder, mix with the pig liver, and form pills the size of a phoenix seed. Each dose is twenty pills, taken at any time with congee.[181p]
    Canglin Tang: Treats rigid mouth diarrhea with heat, characterized by toxic gas disturbing the heart, causing immediate vomiting after eating. Ingredients: ginseng, poria, honey-fried licorice, prepared pinellia, Sichuan pepper, qinghua, ligusticum, balloon flower, bupleurum, bitter orange, and aged grain rice, all in equal parts. Grind and take five qian, with one and a half bowls of water, three slices of fresh ginger, decoct until reduced to seven parts, strain, and take warm at any time.

    Shenling Baizhu Powder: Treats stomach deficiency and rigid mouth. Ingredients: ginseng, poria, white atractylodes, white hyacinth beans (soaked in ginger juice and stir-fried, skins removed), yam, lotus seeds, reduced sand cardamom, and roasted coix seeds, all two taels each. Grind into a fine powder, and take with decocted acorus calamus soup. Eating raw chives is advisable.

    Tongshen Pill: Treats purulent blood diarrhea with heavy pain and prolonged illness. Ingredients: five-spice resin (sand removed and ground), myrrh, frankincense, each one qian, and five fen of croton seed powder. Grind together, add water to form pills about the size of yellow millet, taking seven pills each time. Decoct fresh papaya soup before eating. For children, take three pills, adjusting according to age.[182p]
    Sanqi San: Treats post-diarrhea urgency and heaviness.
    Ingredients: Bitter Orange Peel, Astragalus, Siler.
    Take these in equal parts, grind to a powder, and take two qian mixed with honeyed water or rice drink.

    Baizhu Shengsanzi: Treats any long-term diarrhea and postpartum diarrhea in women.
    Ingredients: Angelica, Nutmeg, Amomum, Pomegranate Peel, Myrobalan flesh, Tangerine Peel, Dry Ginger, Licorice, Atractylodes, Peony.
    Mix these in equal parts, chew, take five qian with two bowls of water, add a small amount of Frankincense, and boil until reduced to one bowl, then strain and take warm before meals.

    Diarrhea Formula:
    For prolonged diarrhea lasting several days, inability to rise, no appetite, and extreme weakness.
    Ingredients: Roasted Rice Husk (2 fen), Ginseng, Astragalus, Ground Dragon (Yiyu), Amomum, and Alisma (each 0.5 qian), Atractylodes, Peony, Tangerine Peel (each 1 qian), Angelica (7 fen), Wood Fragrance, Roasted Licorice, and Bupleurum (each 3 fen).
    Finely chop these to make one dose, using one and a half bowls of water, boil down to one bowl, strain, and take warm.

    Experience Three Roots Decoction: Treats chronic and recurrent diarrhea effectively.
    Ingredients: Fivefold Wood Root, Xanthium Root, and Stinking Ailanthus Root (each in equal parts).
    Finely chop these, take seven qian, add three slices of fresh ginger, one date, thirty-six black beans, forty-nine glutinous rice grains, and two bowls of water, boil down to one bowl, strain, and take warm.[183p]
    Right Return Decoction
    This is a remedy that boosts fire. For any cases of dysentery where Yang is weak and Yin is strong, this formula should be adjusted for use.

    • Prepared Rehmannia: 2-3 qian or increased to 1-2 liang
    • Eucommia Bark: ginger processed,
    • Goji Berries:
    • Honey-fried Dioscorea: each 2 qian
    • Cinnamon:
    • Honey-fried Licorice: each 1-2 qian
    • Processed Aconite: 1-2-3 qian
    • Cornelian Cherry: 1 qian

    For the above, use 2 zhong of water, decoct until there are 7 parts left, and take warm after meals.

    • Paeonia:

    Red Gold Bean
    This treats various accumulations that are stagnant. For any conditions involving blood coagulation, Qi stagnation, pain swelling, parasitic accumulation, symptoms of fullness, and diarrhea, this is to be utilized.

    • Remove the skin and film of Aconitum, reducing the oil: 1.5 qian
    • Fresh Aconite cut, lightly stir-fried
    • Soapberry, stir-fried: each 2 qian
    • Clove:
    • Gardenia:
    • Mu Xiang: each 3 qian
    • Light powder: 1 qian

    The above should be ground into a fine powder, soaked in vinegar, and made into pills the size of radish seeds, with 2 qian of cinnabar as a coating. For gradual passage, take 5-7 pills each time. For rapid passage, take 10-20 pills each time. Use boiling water or decocted medicine, or ginger vinegar tea with honey and fennel for guidance during administration. If diarrhea persists, drinking a few sips of cold water should suffice. This medicine operates with heat and ceases with cold.[184p]
    Bai Shun Pill: Treats all yang pathological accumulations, dysentery, and diarrhea.
    Coptis chinensis (Huang Jin Wen), one pound;
    Fried soapberry (Ya Zao Jiao), lightly yellow, one and a half taels.
    Grind them into powder, use with soup to soak steamed buns, and mold into the size of a large mung bean. Each time, use five fen or one qian, or two to three qian as needed, appropriately taken with some liquid; or made into pills with honey is also acceptable.

    Bao Yin Decoction: Treats all symptoms of yin deficiency and internal heat, and dysentery with blood.
    Raw Rehmannia, cooked Rehmannia, and Peony each two qian;
    Chinese Yam, Sichuan Dextroampelopsis, Huang Qin, Huang Bo each one and a half qian;

    Da Fen Qing Drink: Treats accumulated heat and blockages, obstructed urination, or causes severe pain in the lower back and abdomen, or damp-heat dysentery, jaundice with blood in urine, pathogenic heat engendering blood, abdominal pain, and urinary blockages.
    Poria, Alisma, and Akebia each two qian;
    Polyporus, Bitter Orange Peel, Gardenia (or double the amount), and Plantago seeds each one qian.

    Qingliu Drink: Treats yin deficiency with heat, dysentery, possibly with fever, prefers coolness, pure red fresh blood in stool, or painful urination with redness. Ingredients: 2 portions of raw Rehmannia, Peony, White Poria, and Alisma; 1 portion each of Bitter Orange and Licorice; 1-2 portions of Angelica; 0.5 portions each of Scutellaria and Coptis.     Liuwèi Huāngyáng Drink: Treats spleen and kidney deficiency with cold dysentery. Ingredients: 3 portions of Angelica; 1-2 taels or several portions of Ginseng; 1 portion of roasted Licorice; 2-3 portions each of prepared Aconite and dried Ginger; 5 portions or 1 tael of cooked Rehmannia. Prepare with 2 pints of water, boil with vigorous heat until reduced to 7-8 parts, and take warm.

    Liyin Decoction: This is a modified version of the Zhongtang formula. Treats spleen and kidney deficiency with dysentery. Ingredients: 3-5 portions or 1-2 taels of cooked Rehmannia; 2-3 portions or 5-7 portions of Angelica; 1-2 portions each of roasted Licorice and stir-fried Dried Ginger; optionally add 1-2 portions of Cinnamon. Prepare with 2 pints of water, decoct until reduced to 7-8 parts, and take hot.

    Wengwei Drink: Treats abdominal cold with vomiting, sour regurgitation, dysentery, and loss of appetite. Ingredients: 1-3 portions or 1 tael of Ginseng; 2-3 portions or 1 tael of stir-fried Atractylodes; 2 portions of stir-fried Hyacinth Bean; 1 portion each of roasted Licorice and aged Chenpi (tangerine peel, optional); 1-3 portions of stir-fried Dried Ginger; 1-2 portions of Angelica (omit if diarrhea occurs). Prepare with 2 pints of water, decoct until reduced to 7 parts, and take warm away from meals.[186p]
    Wujunzijian: For treating spleen and stomach deficiency with cold, vomiting, diarrhea, and dysentery accompanied by dampness.
    Ingredients:

    • 2-3 qian of ginseng
    • 2 qian each of white atractylodes (stir-fried) and white poria
    • 1 qian of honey-fried licorice
    • 1-2 qian of stir-fried dry ginger
    • 1.5 bowls of water, decoct and take.
      Add 1 qian of dried tangerine peel, named Liuwei Yigong Decoction, for symptoms of the same but with slight stagnation.

    Weiguan Decoction: For treating spleen and kidney deficiency with cold abdominal pain that does not stop, and cold diarrhea, etc.
    Ingredients:

    • 3-5 qian or 1 liang of cooked rehmannia

    Zhuoguan Decoction: For treating cold damage to the spleen with recent diarrhea and without kidney qi damage, this soup should be used to dispel cold and dampness, and to calm the spleen and stomach. This is an adjunct to Weiguan Decoction.
    Ingredients:

    Yifujian: For treating acute injuries from cold, leading to diarrhea.

      Si Wei San: For treating spleen and kidney deficiency with coldness, especially in cases of severe diarrhea or unstoppable dysentery, or for those with deflated qi, and inability to control blood loss from the two yin, there are no better prescriptions than this.

    Ingredients:

    • Prepared Aconite (Fuzi)
    • Dried Ginger (Ganjiao) (both 2 qian)
    • Honey-fried Licorice (Zhicaocao) (1-2 qian)
    • Grape (Wu Mei) flesh (0.5-1 qian)
    • Ginseng (Ren Shen) (1 liang)

    Grind these into a fine powder, mix well, dampen with water and steam. After cooking, dry it again, then grind into a powder for consumption, taking 1-2 qian mixed with warm water.

    Wu De Wan: For treating spleen and kidney deficiency with coldness, applicable in cases of violent injury from cold, exposure to seasonal cold and damp, or spleen injury from alcohol, resulting in abdominal pain, diarrhea, vomiting, and other symptoms.

    Ingredients:

    • Northern Five-flavor fruit (Beiwuwu) (2 liang), or substitute with meat nutmeg powder, or use Wu Yao
    • Prepared Psoralea (Buguzhi), roasted Dried Ginger (Ganjiao), both 4 liang
    • Prepared Wu Zhu Yu, and Mu Xiang, both 2 liang

    Soak in soup, steam into pill-sized balls similar to the size of a phoenix seed. Each dose consists of 60-70 pills, or up to 100 for severe cases, to be taken with white broth, ginseng soup, or rice soup.

    Fu Yang Dan: For treating symptoms of cold-induced vomiting, diarrhea, abdominal pain, and dysentery.

    Ingredients:

    • Prepared Aconite (Fuzi), roasted Ginger (Pao Jiang), Pepper, Five-flavor fruit, and Honey-fried Licorice (all 1 liang)
    • White flour (2 liang), cooked till browned

    Grind these together into a fine powder, mix well, and form pills the size of a phoenix seed using warm water. Take 1 qian each time, adjusted according to specific symptoms.[188p]
    Nine Qi Pill
    Treats spleen and kidney deficiency with cold, even more so than the Five Virtues Pill.
    Eight taels of cooked Rehmannia, four taels of prepared Aconite, five taels each of roasted Nutmeg, Five Flavors, burnt Ginger, Wu Zhu Yu, and pan-fried Bu Gu Zhi in wine, and fried Peppermint, each two taels; one tael of powdered Licorice.
    Refine into pills with white honey, or form into pills the size of a Wutong seed with yam paste. Take sixty to seventy pills or one hundred pills with boiling white soup.

    Holy Atractylodes Decoction
    Treats injuries from food or drink, cold and damp dysentery, and vomiting; especially a sacred medicine.

    Stagnation at Lower Gate

    Single Prescription
    For dysentery with heat and restlessness: half sheng of polished rice, ground with water to extract juice, placed in a porcelain bottle, sealed with wax paper, and sunk in a well overnight; take in the morning for effectiveness. [From "Pujifang"]
    For diarrhea, avoid food: one sheng of glutinous millet, roasted to remove the white flowers and hulls, mixed with ginger juice and moistened, then roasted again into a powder; take one spoonful with soup, stop after three doses. [From "Experiential Good Prescriptions"][189p]

    1. For continuous dysentery: Take a handful of glutinous rice, two pieces of preserved crucian carp, and a section of Chinese chives, boil them into porridge and consume.

    2. For red and white dysentery: Fry poppy seeds and roast poppy husks, mix them in equal parts into a powder, and form into pills the size of nuts with honey. Take thirty pills each time, swallowed with rice drink.

    3. For hot dysentery with blood in the stool: Use one tael of roasted poppy husk and half a tael of dried tangerine peel powdered together. Take three qian (a unit of weight) each time, with black plum soup.

    4. For red and white dysentery: Mix equal parts of diamond root and wax tea into a powder. Form pills the size of thorny walnuts with white plum flesh. Take five to seven pills each time, or three for children, and use licorice soup for white dysentery or black plum soup for red dysentery.

    5. For dysentery with restricted intake: Take two qian of buckwheat flour and mix with syrupy water to ingest.

    6. For chronic dysentery: Use a small amount of hibiscus seed, dissolve with warm water on an empty stomach, once a day. Avoid green onion, garlic, and their juices. If thirsty, drink honey water to relieve.

    7. For red and white dysentery: Take one fen each of opium, cardamom, Coptis root, and white atractylodes, grind into powder, form into pills the size of beans, one fen for strong individuals, half fen for the elderly and children, taken with rice drink on an empty stomach. Avoid sour, cold, oily, greasy, tea, alcohol, and not stopping substances. If thirsty, drink rice soup.

    8. Additionally, when poppy flowers have not yet bloomed, wrap them in two green leaves. Once they bloom, they fall off; collect them and powder them. Take one qian with rice drink; the effect is miraculous. Use red flowers for red dysentery and white flowers for white dysentery.[190p]

    • For red dysentery with abdominal pain: Take black beans and cornus fruit, rub and swallow them; it is effective.

    • For red and white diarrhea: On the day of the start of autumn in July, face west and swallow seven red beans with well water; you will not suffer from dysentery all autumn.

    • For persistent red dysentery: Grind hemp seeds with water, filter the juice, and cook it with mung beans; it is highly effective. Eating porridge is also acceptable.

    • For long-term dysentery with five colors: Take one ripe loquat, burn it until it is charred, turn it into powder, and take one dose with warm wine; it is effective.

    • For red and white diarrhea: Take powdered mountain bean root, make honey pills the size of wuzi (a type of nut), and swallow twenty pills on an empty stomach with clear soup; three doses will stop the condition.

    • For long-term dysentery leading to sores: Use cassia seed powder and blow it into the rectum with a tube; do this a few times, and it works like magic.

    • For bleeding dysentery that does not stop: Use fermented soybeans and garlic in equal parts, grind them into pills the size of wuzi, and take thirty pills with salty soup.

    • For stabbing blood dysentery: Soak one liter of fermented soybeans in water, boil twice, strain the juice, and consume immediately; if symptoms persist, repeat the process.

    • For severe red and white diarrhea: Cook fermented soybeans until slightly charred, crush into one dose, and take three times a day. Alternatively, fry until charred and soak in water for juice. This is also effective. Another remedy: fry the core of fermented soybeans into powder, split one liter into four doses, take with wine, and it will stop immediately upon entering the mouth.[191p]
      Prolonged dysentery: Cook white tofu with vinegar until browned and consume to recover.

    For blood dysentery that does not stop: Grind earth chrysanthemum and take two qian mixed with sheep's blood, cook it, and eat with fried dough or drink the broth, or boil the earth chrysanthemum to extract juice, reduce it until syrupy, taking a dose of three he at a time, also dissolved in the previous broth.

    For weakened vital energy due to wind invasion into the intestines and stomach, leading to dysentery with red and white stools, pain in the navel and abdomen, urgency with heaviness, thirst, and fullness, with no appetite, mix two liang of dried pancake with honey for frying, and four liang of rice husk with honey for powder, form honey pills the size of a chestnut, take one pill with a bowl of water, boil to dissolve and drink hot.

    For heat toxin dysentery: Take two liang of cattail root and two he of millet, decoct in water and take twice daily.

    For chronic dysentery due to kidney deficiency: Take powdered skeleton fragment and mix it into a pig kidney, stew until cooked and consume, this is effective.

    For red and white dysentery with undigested food: Use yeast to cook millet porridge, take a spoonful each time, four to five times a day.

    For blood dysentery: Grind winter melon seeds, take two qian each time, mix with one qian of aged tea, and adjust with boiling water, take three times a day.

    For watery dysentery: Stir-fry chives into soup and porridge, consume freely, it is beneficial.[192p]
    Red and white diarrhea: Take a handful of green onion whites, finely chopped, and cook with rice to make porridge; consume daily.

    Unstoppable blood diarrhea: Dried ground earth ginseng, take two qian with warm rice water.

    Red diarrhea that does not stop: Cook wild garlic with coptis and take the juice.

    Cold malaria and cold diarrhea: On the Dragon Boat Festival, use ten cloves of single garlic and two qian of yellow lead, pound into balls the size of a locust bean, take nine balls with long-flowing water; this is very effective.

    Unstoppable blood diarrhea: Take five liang of earth skin seeds, one liang each of earth thorn and yellow qin, ground into powder, take a small spoonful with warm water.

    For blood diarrhea with abdominal pain that persists day and night: Take one cup of juice from mustard greens and mix it with one cup of honey; take it warm.

    For diarrhea with restricted diet: Take a small cup of radish juice, one cup of honey, and one cup of water, boil together; take in the morning and afternoon. In the evening, swallow a hundred A-jiao pills with rice water. If radish is unavailable, ground seeds can be used instead. One method adds seven fen of alum and boils together. Another method uses radish greens to make a soup for drinking.

    Additionally: Use radish slices regardless of freshness, soak in honey and let them dissolve; swallow the juice, and if there's a bland taste, replace it. If feeling hungry, cook rice porridge with meat to eat, but not in excess.[193p]
    Diarrhea that does not stop: Grind fresh ginger to a fine powder, mix it with equal parts of dried ginger powder, and use vinegar to knead it into a dough to make dumplings. First, boil it in water, then boil in clear broth, let it cool, and swallow two to seven pieces with porridge once a day.

    Imperial prescription for treating diarrhea: Finely chop fresh ginger and mix it with one bowl of good tea; drink as desired, and it will provide relief. For hot diarrhea, keep the ginger skin; for cold diarrhea, remove the skin, which is very effective.

    For dysentery and bloody diarrhea: Fry one handful of coriander seeds and grind them into powder. Take two qian (a measure) each time. For red dysentery, take with sugar water; for white dysentery, take with ginger broth; for bloody diarrhea, take with clear broth. Do this twice a day.

    For diarrhea, avoid food: Use half-cooked and half-fried yam to make a powder; take two qian each time, mixed with rice drink.

    For persistent diarrhea: Burn eggplant roots to ash, mix with pomegranate peel into powder, and take with sugar water.

    For dysentery, avoid food: Take six seeds of the wood-bitter fruit, remove the shell to retrieve the clean pulp, and grind it into a paste, dividing it into two portions. Use one piece of baked pancake, cut it in half, use only half to create a cavity, placing the medicine inside, then cover it with the other half while warm and apply it to the patient's navel. Replace with another warm pancake when necessary; the diarrhea will stop, leading to a desire for food.[194p]
    Blood Dysentery: For bleeding dysentery, stir-fry five qian of black fungus, grind it, and take it with wine. It can also be used with well water for consumption. Alternatively, boil it with water and add salt and vinegar to eat, using the juice to wash it down.

    Chronic Dysentery: Take two jin of wolf grass, crush and squeeze to extract a small sheng of juice, mix with half a jin of white flour and a little egg, and consume on an empty stomach. In severe cases, do not exceed three doses. Alternatively, dry the seedlings in the shade, crush into powder, and take a thumb-sized measure with half a bowl of honey water.

    Red Dysentery with Abdominal Pain: Steep equal parts aged white plum and true tea with honey water, and drink it.

    Another remedy: Use four liang each of black plum meat and roasted yellow gentian, make honey pills the size of a jujube, and take twenty pills with rice drink, three times a day.

    Dysentery with Pus and Blood: Take one liang of black plum, remove the seeds, roast and grind into powder. Take two qian each time, washed down with rice drink, it will stop immediately.

    Persistent Dysentery with Intestinal Debris: Use twenty pieces of black plum meat, add one bowl of water, boil down to two-thirds, and take in two doses before meals.

    Another method: Use seven pieces each of black plum meat and white plum meat, mash and mix with a little frankincense powder, make pills the size of a jujube, take twenty to thirty pills each time, washed down with tea, three times a day.

    Cold Dysentery: Grind stramonium seeds into powder, mix with lard to form pills as big as jujubes, for anal insertion. If dysentery occurs again, replace with new doses, not exceeding three times, results in recovery.[195p]
    Red and white diarrhea, abdominal pain, and heaviness after bowel movements: Soak half a liang of rhubarb and stir-fry one portion of black colocasia seeds into a powder. Take one qian each time and drink with rice water.

    Dysentery with blood of five colors, sometimes purulent or watery, with imbalance of hot and cold: Take five sour pomegranates, mash them with seeds to extract two sheng of juice, and take five he each time for miraculous effects.

    Unceasing Bloody Diarrhea: Two pieces of snake-shaped stones, calcine with fire and grind to powder, take two qian with rice drink. 【From "Pujifang"】

    Chronic Diarrhea Leading to Ulcers: Mix powder with water and egg white to take, using black feces as standard, to kill parasites and stop the diarrhea.

    Severe Anal Pain from Diarrhea: Boil salt in a bag and apply it to sit on. 【From "Zhouhou Fang," same as above】

    Red and White Diarrhea with Frequent Abdominal Pain: One tael of official powder, egg white mixed and slightly scorched into powder, take one qian with cold spring water.[215p]
    For red and white dysentery: Grind equal parts of yellow lead and fried Coptis into a powder, shape into pills the size of sesame seeds, and take fifty pills with a decoction of ginger and licorice.

    For red and white dysentery: Use three taels of Myrobalan (密陀僧), burn it to yellow, and grind into powder. Take one qian (a measure) with vinegar tea, three times a day.

    For chronic red and white dysentery that has persisted for years: Take a mouthful of powdered muscovite, and after two doses, immediate efficacy will be seen.

    For bloody dysentery with abdominal pain: Take five qian of greasy powder and three qian of fixed powder, grind and soak in water; steam a little dough and mix into pills the size of mung beans. Take seven or ten pills with an egg and one cup of water, decoct and consume.

    Acupuncture

    The "Jia Yi Classic" states: For sudden illness with headache, body heat, muscle ache, deafness to wind, red and tearing eyes, an inability to look sideways, pain in the hip joint, and loose intestines, treat with the governing spine. For intestinal pain and loose bowels, treat accordingly.

    For pus in stool, internal cold, undigested food, and abdominal pain, treatment is at the Compassionate Yin point. For diarrhea and abdominal pain with visceral obstruction, treatment is at the Earth Mechanism point.

    For intestinal issues, treat at the Middle Valley point. For bloody stools with underlying cold, treat at the Ququan and Wuli points. If there is internal cold causing bloody diarrhea, treat at the Meeting Yang point. For gurgling intestines and loose stools, treat at the Lower Yin point.[216p]
    The "Thousand Gold Prescriptions" states: For treating thunder rumbling in the intestines, accompanied by diarrhea, apply moxibustion at Chengman with fifty strong strokes. The point is located two and a half inches on either side of the Xiajuque. Xiajuque is located one inch below the heart.

    For diarrheal discharge of pus and blood, with severe pain in the lower abdomen, moxibustion at the small intestine point should be done with a hundred strong strokes.

    For diarrhea causing loss of appetite and inability to digest food, even when eating, moxibustion at Changgu should be done with fifty strong strokes and three reports. The point is five inches away from the navel.

    For diarrhea characterized by red and white, moxibustion at the foot Taiyin should be done with fifty strong strokes and three reports.

    For chronic diarrhea that does not heal despite numerous treatments, moxibustion should be done at the point one inch below the foot Yangming, in the hollow of the bone, three inches from the big toe, adjusted according to the patient’s strength.

    Another method: Bend a bamboo measure to the appropriate length on the spine above the hips; measure down one inch to mark on either side, and again measure down one inch on the spine. Moxibustion should be applied at these three points, thirty strong strokes for each, or more than a hundred strokes altogether. This treatment can halt all types of diarrhea. It also treats cold-type diarrhea (with hidden worms), but do not apply moxibustion on the spine at the points above the hips. Also, apply moxibustion on the navel with two to three hundred strong strokes. Additionally, moxibustion at Guanyuan should be done with three hundred strong strokes over ten days, which treats abdominal pain from cold-type diarrhea located three inches below the navel.

    For diarrhea with both red and white discharge, apply moxibustion at Qionggu, with a preference for more strokes.

    Jiaoxin is indicated for diarrhea with red and white leaking blood.
    Fuliu indicates intestinal purging, with pus and blood in defecation, heavy post-diarrhea and abdominal pain resembling cramps.
    XiaoChangshu is indicated for diarrhea featuring pus and blood in various colors, along with swelling and pain in the lower abdomen.
    Shugu is related to intestinal purging and diarrhea.[217p]
    Tai Bai (the planet Venus) is associated with abdominal distension, inability to digest food, tendency to vomit and have diarrhea, and also with pus and blood.

    Tai Chong and Qu Quan are associated with dysentery, especially with blood in the stool.

    For red and white dysentery, apply moxibustion to the Small Intestine points fifty times.

    The "Medical Essentials" states: when there is stagnation in the lower abdomen, focus on the Foot Taiyin meridian. The scripture states: diseases arising from the Spleen Foot Taiyin Meridian manifest as masses, diarrhea, and dysentery. One should observe the symptoms of excess and deficiency, heat and cold, and treat accordingly. For urgency and heaviness, use He Gu and Wai Guan points.

    Guided Movements

    The "Secret Essentials for Health Preservation" states: for the treatment of dysentery through guided movements, clench the perineum, stand with feet together, concentrate your spirit with your gaze, hang down both fists straight, draw in your abdomen and raise your shoulders, using your mind to pull up your energy. Inhale, allowing three breaths without interruption, and direct the energy upwards to stop the diarrhea.

    First, circulate energy to gather and consolidate it before pushing it through the Large Intestine, allowing for the flow to release heat, then draw it back and focus on the navel, seeking tranquility and waiting for the diarrhea to stabilize, supplementing energy as needed.

    Another method is: push open the Lung Meridian, releasing through the nine bends of the Large Intestine; then rise with Kidney water to cleanse the Lung Meridian.

    For mouth-related dysentery: push from the heart to the kidneys, envisioning Kidney water rising to the crown of the head to cleanse the heart, restoring balance in the navel and practicing the circulation method.

    For summer heat-induced dysentery: circulate water to cleanse the Lung Meridian, then push through the nine bends of the Large Intestine; after stopping the diarrhea, focus on the navel for recovery.

    The method of gathering energy: the Earth represents the original essence. With a focused heart, nourish in the Earth, letting all senses return to the origin; concentrate the heart for a long time, and you will feel the true essence always present, at which point you may use your mind to circulate energy.[218p]
    The method of practice involves raising the intent upwards, circulating within the processes of nature, moving from left to right. First, cultivate the dantian, gathering and releasing, releasing and then gathering again, returning to the original state. Do not stray from this, and the mind will return to the truth.

    As for the method of circulating the whole body: first establish stability and guard the center, and once the techniques are mastered, perform circulation throughout the body to disperse stagnant energy in the limbs. The practice begins with movement at the dantian, expanding from small to large and then back to small, ascending sequentially to the Xuanzhi point, circling around the left arm, and descending to the Quqi and Neiguan points, tracing the palm and fingertips, circling the back of the wrist, ascending to the elbow, shoulder well, and Dachui, then moving down to the tailbone, and returning upward, passing over the Yuzhen, surpassing the Kunlun, above the facial area, and descending the Magpie Bridge to reach the stomach, crossing the dantian to the Yuzhu, then circulating to the right leg, passing the knee, penetrating through the Xiaolao point to the top of the foot and to the fingertips, turning at the Yongquan, rising at the heel, passing over the Yingu, connecting to the tailbone, and circling to the crown of the head. Following the descent from the Magpie Bridge, similarly send energy down the left leg as done on the right, then ascending through the Niwan and Xuanzhi on the right side, illuminating the left hand, turning over the shoulder and back, channeling through Kunlun and then down to gather yuanqi. In this way, the meridians throughout the body will become unimpeded, slowly revolving. As the mind directs, the energy naturally follows. This is the method of circulating the whole body that can also interact with nature.[219p]

    Medical Case

    According to the "Ten Books of Dongyuan": In the winter of the Gui-Mao year, in the Bai Shu household, there was an old man with a dusty face and a notably weak spirit. He had been suffering from a long-standing case of rectal prolapse, had not found relief from medicines, and was also experiencing both red and white purulent dysentery, accompanied by a feeling of urgency and heaviness in the abdomen; there was more white than red, and he could not endure the pain in search of a cure. I said: This is not due to meat and rich foods but rather from a diet high in vegetables or irregular eating habits. Though the weather is cold, his clothing remains thin; he is unable to resist and his intestines have fallen due to cold. The true qi cannot be retained, and the bodily form is not consolidated, resulting in the blood being loose and slipping. This is due to a failure of cold and slippery qi to hold firm, causing the bodily form to descend. I will use a medicinal powder made from the skin of the haritaki fruit to relieve his prolapse and eliminate the slippery condition; its slightly sour taste will help to consolidate and raise the qi. I will administer a strongly warming medicinal formula to dispel the cold and or restore yang; using qi-replenishing herbs will elevate yang, enhance qi, and provide stability.[220p]
    The text states: As I turned over fifty, I suffered from a blockage in the lower abdomen during the summer, experiencing mild pain in the belly and dark-colored excretions. There was frequent heaviness, a significant reduction in appetite, and occasional slight fever. Upon examining the pulse, it was found to be string-like and deficient, slightly rapid yet somewhat elongated, without being overly floating. Both hands had equal strength, and I observed a substantial decrease in vitality. I concluded that this was not merely a blockage but a result of worry, with heart blood deficiency and weak spleen qi. Therefore, I prescribed ginseng and atractylodes as the main ingredients, with angelica, tangerine peel as assistants, and fried ligusticum, white peony, and poria as adjuncts. Given the intense heat, I added a little coptis, and after two days, the patient was at ease.

    As for Chief Mei, over thirty years old and well-nurtured, he suffered blockage in the lower abdomen during the summer and autumn, experiencing significant pain. Someone advised him to take single-boiled dried ginger, which alleviated the pain temporarily. However, the pain recurred shortly thereafter, and again he took the ginger, which provided relief. Consequently, he consumed three pounds of dried ginger over time. After eight days, I examined him again; the left pulse was string-like and somewhat stronger, while the right pulse was string-like yet slightly weaker. The pulse felt tense upon further inspection. I suggested that he must have overeaten and consumed excessive cold substances, hence it should be treated as a deficiency of cold. Due to the excessive intake of dried ginger, I prescribed the Four Substances Decoction omitting rehmannia, adding ginseng, atractylodes, tangerine peel, wine-red flower, poria, and peach kernel, decocted with fresh ginger juice, and after a month, he was stable.[221p]
    The wife of the Jin family was nearly forty years old. In early autumn, it was still hot, and she suffered from a stagnation below, experiencing only dull abdominal pain, which was worse at night than during the day, preventing her from sleeping entirely. Her appetite had slightly decreased, and she felt dry in her mouth without thirst. She had already taken two doses of a remedy for dysentery. Upon examination, both of her pulses were weak and irregular, and she appeared very fatigued. Her food intake was significantly reduced, so I prescribed the Four Substance Decoction, increasing the amount of white atractylodes as the main ingredient, with dried tangerine peel as an aid, and after taking a dozen doses, she felt settled.

    Brother Zheng from Pujiang was nearly sixty years old and was a person cared for and receiving assistance. In the middle of summer, he had long suffered from stagnation below and also had overexerted himself in sexual activity. One evening, while going to the toilet, he suddenly relaxed, his eyes opened without light, he urinated involuntarily, sweated profusely, and felt as if his throat was being pulled and sawed, with very faint breathing; his pulse was large and erratic, showing no clear position, which was very alarming. I happened to be there and quickly ordered ginseng paste to be prepared, and also instructed to moxibustion at the Qihai point with moxa cones the size of a little finger—up to eighteen cones, he regained movement in his right hand; after three more cones, his lips began to move slightly. The ginseng paste was ready, and I gave him one cup. By midnight, after consuming three cups, he could move his eyes; after finishing two pounds, he was able to speak and asked for congee. After finishing five pounds, the diarrhea stopped, and with ten pounds, he felt at ease.[222p]
    The "Danxi Heart Method" states: An elderly man, aged seventy, had a pale face, with thin, rapid pulses; only his stomach pulse was deep and slippery. After drinking white wine, he developed dysentery, passing blood with thin pus and had abdominal pain, with difficult urination and urgency. I prescribed ginseng and atractylodes as the main ingredients, with licorice, talc, areca nut, wood incense, and common atractylodes as assistants, and gave him twenty-five pills of Baohe Wan. The next day, all symptoms had diminished, but he still had difficulty urinating, so I administered Yiyuan San, and he was stable.

    Zhao Lidao, nearing fifty, had a weak constitution and frequently lost his temper. In July, during the intense heat of summer and amidst great hunger, his family could not quickly provide food, which led to a great anger. Two days later, he developed stagnation and had difficulty with bowel movements, feeling thirsty, so he mixed cold water with honey to drink, which provided relief, and the stagnation gradually eased over five to seven days. When I was called to examine him, the pulse was slightly stronger but not rapid. I ordered him to stop drinking honey water. When thirsty, I instructed him to drink a decoction of ginseng and white atractylodes, along with Yiyuan San, and the stagnation continued to improve.

    After seven to eight days, he felt very fatigued and began to belch; I knew this was due to prolonged diarrhea leading to Yin deficiency, so I instructed him to continue with the previous medication. However, the stagnation had not yet ceased, and he was still drinking honey. After three days, the belching had not stopped. Many attributed this to improper medication and suggested ginger and fuzi (prepared aconite) be added. I said, "Tonics do not have immediate effects; fuzi is not for nourishing Yin, and taking it could be fatal." They said, "He drank a lot of cold water—could that be the cause of the cold?" I replied, "In such intense heat, drinking something cool isn’t the same as being cold—do not doubt too much, wait a few days; when the medicine takes effect, it will naturally stop." After another four days, the belching ceased and the bowel issues were also resolved.[223p]
    Chen Zeren was nearly seventy years old, a person of considerable substance. He had a lingering cough for a long time, which occasionally ceased. In early autumn, he suffered from a blockage in his lower abdomen, reducing his appetite significantly, leading to vomiting after five or seven days. He summoned me to examine him; his pulse was notably large, and many thought it difficult. I said: A person who is thin can still be treated. I administered a ginseng and white atractylodes decoction along with a major tonic pill to replenish his blood, and he was stable after seven days.

    My paternal uncle, robust in both form and complexion, was suffering from intermittent fever and also dysentery. He relied on his strength and ability to eat, without any caution. One day, he called for me and said: I am healthy and able to eat, yet I have profuse sweating; can you stop this sweat? I replied: The intermittent fever is not the sweating that hinders recovery; what is concerning is your strength and ability to eat. This is not dysentery. Your stomach is hot and well-digested; the spleen is struggling with food residue, and the condition has become severe. At this time, it is wise to regulate your diet to nourish your stomach energy, minimizing exposure to wind and cold, and wait for the sweat to pass for stability.

    He said: People say that one cannot die from dysentery while still able to eat; since I can eat, what is there to worry about? I replied: If one can eat but has dysentery, it indicates that the stomach energy is not yet affected, hence the claim of not dying. It is not about overindulging in eating without selection. Ignoring my advice, he indulged in excessive eating and also consumed fruits. After a month of this, he sought treatment, but it was too late to intervene. After another month, he passed away. The Inner Canon states that arrogance is not to be discussed in reason and is a disease that cannot be treated; how true this is![224p]
    The Zhou person was robust in both body and appearance but suffered from dysentery. He had a good appetite but was easily hungry, devouring food indiscriminately for five months. I admonished him, saying: "While ill, one should nourish oneself appropriately; how can you indulge in flavors that harm your body?" Therefore, I advised him to eat only cooked radishes and congee, and to take fewer remedies, which led to his recovery after half a month.

    In the "Notes on Nurturing Illness," it is recorded that Emperor Xiaozong once suffered from dysentery, and despite the ineffectiveness of many doctors, De Shou was worried about him. While passing through the palace, he happened to see a small pharmacy and sent a messenger to inquire, "Can you treat dysentery?" The response was: "It is my specialty." The messenger then brought him in to ask about the cause of the illness, and it was mentioned that he had eaten too many river crabs, leading to this ailment. He was then asked to check the pulse and diagnosed it as a type of cold dysentery. The prescribed method involved using freshly harvested lotus root segments, finely ground, to be taken with hot wine. Following this method, with the root ground finely and mixed with wine for several doses, he soon recovered. De Shou was greatly pleased and consequently gifted him the golden pestle and mortar, which have since been referred to as the "Golden Pestle Mortar of Strict Defense."[225p]
    In the "Correct Transmission of Medicine," it is stated: There was a man nearing fifty who suffered from dysentery for more than a month in summer and autumn. Although he took medicine, he improved only slightly; his bowel movements had stopped, yet he could not eat, going to the toilet five to six times a day and also experiencing discomfort from prolapsed rectum for another half month, with no remedy proving effective. I remembered a formula passed down from my ancestors, which involved using a turtle from a pond. Following the method, I prepared it mainly with fresh ginger and a small piece of rock sugar, avoiding salt and sauces. After cooking it thoroughly, he consumed one or two bowls. Within three days, he did not need to go to the toilet, and from then on, his large intestine was functional, and the rectum returned to normal. This condition was likely due to a deficiency in the spleen, leading to a lack of nourishment for both the lungs and the large intestine. Thus, the large intestine was unable to function properly. The turtle, categorized as a shellfish and having an element of earth, is warm and can nourish the spleen and lungs. Moreover, the lungs, having been exposed to cold due to previous treatments involving bitter and cold herbs, now required warming. Therefore, ginger, which is spicy, was used to restore the lung's metal element, and the sweetness of rock sugar was employed to fortify the spleen's earth element. Once the lung energy was sufficient, the large intestine also became robust, allowing it to regain its function. Hence, the effectiveness of this method was evident.[226p]
    The "Medical Compendium" states: My elder brother experienced stagnant bowel issues in September, having over fifty bouts each night, with vomiting and inability to keep food down. After five or six days, he additionally suffered from hiccups. By holding a small piece of clove in his mouth, the hiccups stopped immediately. However, they returned shortly after, so he took Huanglian Xiexin Decoction, adding some bamboo leaf to drink. Although the hiccups reduced, the bowel issues remained uneasy for over ten days. He then took a small amount of glutinous rice husk on an empty stomach to relieve the discomfort. During the day, he supplemented his weakness with ingredients such as ginseng, atractylodes, and dried tangerine peel. After consuming the glutinous rice husk, his hiccup sounds gradually lessened, and his bowel condition was ultimately stabilized.[227p]
    The "Medical Cases of Xue Ji" states: Cui Sikong, over sixty years old, suffered from dysentery with both red and white stools, experiencing urgency and a heavy feeling afterward. This was due to damp-heat stagnation, so he was treated with Shao Yao Decoction, adding two qian of Da Huang, and after one dose was reduced by half, he was cured with another full dose. However, the urgency persisted; this indicated a sinking of the spleen qi, treated with Bu Zhong Yi Qi to regulate and send Xiang Lian Wan for recovery.

    Luo Ge Shi experienced acute pain in the lower abdomen, with a desire to defecate but unable to do so, indicating deficiency and sinking of the spleen and kidney qi. Two doses of Bu Zhong Yi Qi and Ba Wei Wan were used, leading to recovery. Such cases arise from dysentery medications damaging the original qi, resulting in limb swelling and even death, which are too numerous to count.

    Shao Zongbo visited Gu Dongjiang, who had stopped eating due to dysentery and felt abdominal pain with a downward sensation. Some used purgative medicines, resulting in swelling in both legs, reduced appetite, fatigue, irritability, thirst with a rapid pulse, which felt thin upon examination. I prescribed Liu Jun Decoction with an addition of two qian each of ginger and cinnamon, and one qian each of Wu Zhu Yu and Wu Wei, simmered until cooked and taken cold. After sleeping, all symptoms rapidly diminished; with a second dose, all symptoms completely disappeared. This condition was characterized by true internal cold and false external heat, thus treated with a warming remedy and cold drink.[228p]
    Judge Wang Tianxi, over sixty years old, suffered from dysentery and severe abdominal pain. He experienced thirst and was sensitive to cold, with food intake impaired. A prescription of Shao Yao Decoction was enhanced with an ounce of Da Huang, which showed some effect after four doses, but the previous prescription was continued with Da Huang reduced by half, and after several doses he recovered. Such vitality is quite rare.

    A female patient experienced severe dysentery afterward and knew the medicinal approach. She took Shao Yao Decoction, but her condition worsened with minimal appetite, cold abdomen, and cold limbs. It was deemed a deficiency in the spleen and stomach, so she was treated with Liu Junzi Decoction augmented with Mu Xiang and Pao Jiang, and she recovered.

    The Grand Attendant Yang Juyuan initially had food stagnation with a heavy feeling in the lower abdomen. He took Liu Junzi Decoction with Sheng Ma and Chai Hu and gradually improved. Later, he had difficulty digesting food, with loose bowels and a sense of urgency in the abdomen, making repeated visits to the latrine without success. He was treated with Sheng Yang Zhi Shi Fang and was cured. Subsequently, he experienced pain in the heart and abdomen with a lack of appetite. He was then given He Zhong Wan with a double dose of Yi Zhi Ren and soon recovered.

    An elderly woman developed dysentery after eating due to anger, with urgency in the abdomen and a heavy feeling. This was attributed to the descent of spleen qi. She was prescribed a large dose of Liu Junzi Decoction supplemented with Fu Zi, Mu Guo, and Pao Mu Xiang each at a qian, Wu Yao at half a qian, Guo Zhi, and Wu Wei at one and a half qian each. After two doses, all symptoms subsided. However, she still felt distension in the lower abdomen, which was due to liver qi stagnation affecting the spleen. She took Tiao Zhong Yi Qi Decoction with an addition of Fu Zi and Mu Xiang at half a qian and was cured after four doses. Later, she felt a salty taste in her mouth, indicating kidney deficiency with water retention, and was treated with Liu Wei Di Huang Decoction for recovery.[229p]
    My late mother, aged eighty, suffered from summer dysentery with abdominal pain, vomiting, and loss of appetite. She experienced heat and thirst, craving for soup, and found slight relief from pressing her abdomen. Her pulse was strong and forceful, indicating a deficiency of true qi and an excess of pathogenic qi. In response, I urgently administered five qian of ginseng, three qian each of white atractylodes and poria, and one qian each of dried tangerine peel, bulbus cimicifugae, aconite, and roasted licorice. After taking this remedy, she desired food and her symptoms significantly lessened; a second dose provided her with peace, demonstrating that symptoms should be prioritized over the pulse in acute illnesses. At that time, Lady Shi Ge, of the same age and exhibiting similar symptoms, specialized in treating her dysentery but ultimately failed to recover.

    As for Ting Ping Qu Ru, after meals he returned to his room and experienced abdominal pain that seemed like dysentery but was not quite so. The next day, he had purulent blood in his stools, accompanied by restlessness and thirst, and felt mentally sluggish and fatigued. A dose of the Four Spirits Pill resulted in quick improvement. Additionally, he took Eight Flavor Pills, enhanced with five flavors, Wu youtang, bone fat, and nutmeg, and was completely cured after two doses.

    Sima Wang Jingshan suffered from severe dysentery; after taking bitter orange peel and betel nuts, his condition worsened. He ate little and had abdominal pain. I believed his spleen and stomach were damaged, resulting in a deficiency and cold state. Thus, I used Six Gentleman Decoction with added agastache and processed ginger, and he recovered.[230p]
    Li Yi from the Ministry of Rites suffered from blood dysentery, with a swollen chest and abdomen, an urge to defecate without result, and extreme fatigue in the limbs. This was due to a weakness of spleen qi, which could not hold the blood and restore it to its source. I treated him with a formula to tonify the middle and boost qi, adding Poria and Pinellia, and he gradually recovered. Later, due to anger, the previous symptoms reappeared. The left guan pulse was string-taut and floating, and upon palpation it was weak. This indicated a deficiency of the liver that could not store the blood, so I treated him with the Six-Flavor Pill, and he recovered.

    The "Comprehensive Medicine of Ancient and Modern Times" states: A patient suffering from dysentery and urgency precisely matches the symptoms of the purgative syndrome. I noted that the qi pulse was weak, and although the body appeared full, the complexion was pale and yellow, indicating past overeating had damaged the stomach. I then used ginseng, white atractylodes, dried tangerine peel, and peony in more than ten doses. After three months, his stomach qi had improved somewhat, and I prescribed two doses of the purgative decoction, and he was at ease. If one does not first tonify, although they may recover, they will still feel exhausted.

    A patient presented with a pale complexion and a string-taut pulse, the gastric pulse being deep and slippery. After consuming white liquor, he had dysentery with clear watery pus and blood, abdominal pain, difficulty urinating, and a feeling of urgency and heaviness in the lower abdomen. I used ginseng and white atractylodes as the main herbs, with licorice, talc, cardamom, betel nut, and bitter atractylodes as assistants, brewing a decoction and administering twenty pills of Baohuan Pill. The following day, his symptoms diminished, but he still had difficulty urinating. I prescribed several doses of Yiyuan Powder, and he recovered.

    Another patient suffered from dysentery with slight abdominal pain, passing dark brown stools, feeling heavy and frequent urges to defecate, reduced appetite, and slight fever. The pulse was string-taut and thin, seemingly rapid yet long; he showed a lack of vitality. I diagnosed this as arising from worry and distress, leading to heart blood deficiency and weak spleen qi. Using ginseng and atractylodes as the main herbs, with angelica, dried tangerine peel as ministers, and chuanxiong, peony, poria, and coptis as assistants, he recovered.[231p]
    "The Essential Medical Texts" states: Lady Sun Xiaoxiang, who suffered from dysentery for forty days, experienced dry mouth, fever, lack of appetite, abdominal bloating, and undigested food. There were those who argued that the invading heat did not harm the food. She took over thirty prescriptions of Xiang, Lian, Zhi Ke, Dou Kou, and Hou Po, but after five days of fasting, her life was in danger. When I was called to diagnose her, her pulse was large and rapid; upon palpation, it was clear that her abdominal pain subsided with pressure, and her urination was clear and smooth. This indicated that the fire was weak and could not generate earth, showing true cold internally but false heat externally. I urgently prepared a decoction of Fu Zi and Li Zhong Tang and administered it cold, leading to the relief of pain after one dose, and after six doses, her fever subsided and she was able to eat. After taking Ba Wei Wan for over twenty days, she recovered remarkably.

    In Huaian County, the daughter of Lord Xu Tongsheng suffered from dysentery and abdominal pain, with a pulse that was weak and soft, indicative of qi deficiency unable to transform essence. Her urgency and heaviness were due to prolapse. I used Sheng Yang San Huo Tang for one dose, followed by ten doses of Bu Zhong Yi Qi Tang, which led to her recovery.

    In the case of Wenxue Gu Weinan, he had dysentery for a month, with all medicines proving ineffective. I diagnosed him with both qi and blood deficiency, proposing a heavy supplementation. All medications for dysentery were halted. I prescribed ten doses of Shi Quan Da Bu Tang and, alongside that, twenty doses of Bu Zhong Yi Qi added with ginger and cinnamon, achieving a state of calm.[232p]
    During autumn, General Zhang Qing'an suffered from dysentery. He tried various remedies like Xiang, Lian, Zhi, and Pu for two months, but his condition did not improve. Upon examination, his pulse was slippery yet strong, indicating that he had lost his ability to expel. I used a combination of Xiang, Lian, Gui, Shao, Chenpi, and Zhihua, along with three qian of Dahuang, leading to a considerable expulsion of waste. His pulse remained strong, so I continued with the same prescription, considering the accumulation as substantial as fish intestines. After over ten days of treatment, he recovered.

    The official Mao Ru initially had dysentery that presented with severe abdominal pain and gurgling sounds, leading to vomiting upon the sight of food. He had only taken Qinshi, Lian, Muxiang, Changpu, Huoxiang, Juhong, and Shaoyao. Later, someone administered Si Jun Zi Tang, which I found dubious but didn’t pursue further. He called for me at night for a diagnosis. Although his pulse was full and large, it felt weak under pressure, especially at the right wrist, where it was particularly soft. I deduced that the fire at the life gate was weak and could not generate Earth, thus he urgently needed Ren and Fu to restore Yang. Ru said: “If I only use Ren and Shu, can he recover?” I replied: “Without Gui and Fu, even with Ren and Shu, it would not benefit the illness. Moreover, the Spleen Earth is greatly deficient; deficiency requires to supplement the Mother, does it not? Thus, I prescribed five qian of Ren, one and a half qian of Fu, one qian of Paojiang, and three qian of Baizhu, administering three doses, after which vomiting ceased and he could eat congee. Further, I added Bu Zhong Yi Qi with ginger and Fu; after fourteen doses, he was able to attend to matters again.[233p]
    The "Remarkable Remedies" states: Emperor Taizong of the Tang dynasty suffered from dysentery and issued an edict promising a heavy reward for anyone who could cure his illness. A practitioner named Zhang Baozang presented this remedy and was rewarded with a third-rank official position. The recipe includes half a liter of cow's milk and two qian of powdered ginger, boiled down by half and taken on an empty stomach.

    In the past, there was a person who suffered from dysentery, experiencing pus and blood in his stools. He suddenly saw sweet melons soaked in water and, filled with delight, ate several pieces with the skin, after which the pus and blood ceased.

    Chen Qing's eldest son, around ten years old, suffered from severe dysentery, unable to take water or grain for several days, only able to take medicine. A person used powdered yam mixed with rice water for him, and after one dose, the dysentery became slightly better; after three doses, he craved porridge and was able to consume about half a bowl, after which his dysentery stopped and he felt at ease.[234p]
    The "Medical Comprehensive Treatise" states: A pregnant woman experienced both malaria and dysentery simultaneously, and was treated for more than two months. The malaria subsided, but the dysentery worsened, accompanied by abdominal pain and reduced appetite, prompting me to examine her again. I said: This is a condition of deficiency and cold. I prescribed a restorative formula to boost the central qi, adding ginger and cinnamon. After one dose, the dysentery improved significantly; after a second dose, however, the malaria symptoms intensified alarmingly. The host was frightened, but I reassured them: This is a good sign. The prior cessation of malaria indicated an extreme dominance of yin, causing yang to refrain from confrontation. Now, with a tonic for yang, the yang energy is fortified enough to contend with yin, thus helping yang's strength and allowing yin to recede. I added five grams of prepared aconite to the prescription, and both malaria and dysentery were cured. After taking a large restorative dose, three months later she gave birth to a son, and she was very healthy after childbirth.

    The "Meaning in Herbs" states: Zhu Kongyang, aged twenty-five, was slender and accustomed to a life of leisure. During the summer months, due to involvement in a lawsuit, he was out during the hot midday, causing internal heat from the combined effects of heat and humidity, resulting in dysentery. He experienced frequent bowel movements, one to two hundred times a day, unable to get out of bed. He laid coarse paper on his bedding, replacing it frequently, only able to drink water but unable to eat, suffering intensely with rectal pain that felt like being burned. He would flail his limbs, restless and miserable. I examined his pulse, which was tight and forceful, refusing to yield under pressure. I remarked: This condition signifies a mass of toxic fire, trapped within the intestines and stomach, burning fiercely. Immediate rescue is necessary; if delayed by two or three days, the intestines and stomach will rot away.[235p]
    Then, four taels of rhubarb, two taels each of coptis and licorice were put into a large sand pot for decoction, taken while boiling, and consumed. After taking the medicine, the person was somewhat calm for a moment, but shortly thereafter, the restlessness returned for a whole day and night. After taking more than twenty bowls, the rhubarb had completely dissolved, and the coptis and licorice were boiled down to dryness. The next day, the patient again requested the previous medicine. After the diagnosis, I saw the pulse was somewhat softer and knew the illness could be cured, but I opted for an urgent method instead of urgent medicine. Thus, I changed to four taels each of raw rehmannia and ophiopogon, and separately extracted their fresh juices. I then added one tael each of powdered trichosanthes, peony bark, red peony, and licorice, and decocted them into a large bowl of harmonious fluid to drink. Because the onset was fierce, all bodily fluids had been depleted, and one must wait for the diarrhea to stop before nourishing the blood and fluids, as recovering from such depletion would take time. Now that the pulse had softened, the fiery pathogen had retreated; if one did not treat the diarrhea, it would stop on its own. How could one rely on lubricating and stagnating medicines without urgent action? After taking this medicine, indeed the diarrhea ceased completely, leaving only a little residual froth. On the third day, the patient craved tofu soup. On the fourth day, I gradually introduced clear broth from old warehouse rice. Slowly adjusting over ten days, he was eventually able to digest grains. It was also noted that the presence of stomach qi must not overlook this urgent matter at hand.[236p]
    Chen Ruming was suffering from dysentery, with fever as if steamed, heavy and unable to eat, feeling extremely unwell. On the third day, in critical condition, he requested my diagnosis. His pulse was rapid and considerably hollow, with the pulse at the wrist being especially strong. I said: This is a case where two illnesses coincide at one time. Internally, there is damp-heat combining with the external heat of the season, wanting to manifest as dysentery, yet he remained unaware, having also engaged in excessive sexual activity, which contributed to being suddenly attacked by cold. Hence, the fever, heaviness, and inability to eat are all related to the external invasion of the Lesser Yin Kidney channel. When the Lesser Yin is affected, one should expect diarrhea of clear fluids. This is because the damp-heat in the intestines has already boiled into a foul form resembling pig liver or fish brain; thus, although the color changes, the diarrhea remains the same. If I were to administer a remedy for dysentery at this point, it would be of no help. I hastily gave him a dose of Mahuang, Fuzhu, and Xixin Decoction to dispel the external pathogen, and after sweating, his heat slightly diminished. Then, I used Fuzhu Lizhong Decoction as well, giving two doses; the heat receded, and he felt lighter and was able to eat. I switched to taking Huanglian Lizhong Pills, and by the tenth day, he was completely well.[237p]
    Ye Maoqing, a young boy, suffered from dysentery and was instructed not to eat. He had a fever for more than ten days, with continuous vomiting. Upon examining his pulse, it was surging upward without a root; the pulse in his feet showed the same condition. I told his father: "This is not a case of dysentery caused by dietary restriction; rather, it is a sign that the stomach's qi is about to fail. In dysentery from dietary restriction, there is virtual heat in the stomach, stagnating and not dispersing, hence the sensation of fullness without appetite. The treatment should focus on nourishing deficiency and clearing heat. This condition arises from the harm of bitter and cold medicines, which cannot accept food; thus, warm nourishment is the only remedy."

    I then administered two doses of the "Li Zhong Tang" (Regulating the Center Decoction). In no time, he experienced ten or more bouts of dysentery, and the surroundings became messy. Maoqing feared that the medicine was inappropriate for his condition and requested a different prescription. I replied: "My aim is to first save the qi of the stomach from failing, and I am not treating the dysentery directly. Dysentery involves the large and small intestines, which are quite distant in the body; even a miraculous pill cannot instantly change the stool. Encouraging it to come out quickly with medicine is indeed a good thing—how could that be doubted?"

    So, I continued the previous medicine for another two days. His condition greatly improved; he began to feel hungry without vomiting, and the dysentery's intensity decreased. Four days later, he only passed damp remnants. After restoring the Qi with nourishing methods and regulating his condition for ten days, he fully recovered. This illustrates that in children with dysentery, even if they have consumed food that harms the stomach, it is rare to find accumulated heat inside. Thus, it is particularly inadvisable to lightly apply the standard methods for treating dysentery.[238p]
    Mr. Pu Junyi fell ill with dysentery. At first, he had an outward pathogen that had not yet dispersed, but mistakenly used ginseng and atractylodes to strengthen the exterior, allowing the pathogenic qi to penetrate deeply. He also mistakenly took huanglian to cool and resolve heat, and da huang to purge, which he did for more than a month, resulting in his stomach qi being out of order, with over a hundred watery stools in one day. One evening, he vomited three to five bowls of the yellow lotus medicine, and after vomiting two or three times, his stomach and intestines seemed to become one. The pylorus and the lower orifice were wide open without obstruction; not only did the congee and drink flow straight out, but even ginseng extract, once swallowed, rushed down immediately from the intestines. In this critical situation, various friends and relatives asked me: "Is there no fear in this condition?" I replied, "With the medicine I’m using, there is something to rely on. Am I unaware of the severity of this illness? But there is no one else to depend on; I will temporarily calm him down while doing my best to inform his supporters." Thus, I prescribed a large dose of the Four Gentlemen Decoction, decocted with powdered red stone fat and Yu Yu grain, and continuously administered it. After taking it, the rate of diarrhea diminished slightly, but he experienced unbearable abdominal pain. Junyi said: "Although I had much diarrhea before, there was no pain. After taking this medicine, the pain increased; it cannot be taken again." I replied: "This is precisely the saying that when it flows, there is no pain; when there is pain, it does not flow. If it does not flow, it is dangerous; if it hurts, it is safe. Why would one not prefer to feel pain?" I continued with the previous medicine. Once the condition improved significantly, I then used an increased amount of the Four Gentlemen Decoction with more than ten doses of poria to ensure complete safety.[239p]
