    For both types of dysentery: On the fifth day of the fifth month, gather equal parts of Artemisia and mugwort, mix with fermented soybeans to make cakes, dry them in the sun. Each time, take one cake and decoct in one and a half cups of water.

    Red and white diarrhea: Five qian of dragon's tooth herb, a pinch of aged tea, decoct in water and take; it is remarkably effective.

    For heat toxin leading to red and white diarrhea: Take one jin of good tea, roast and grind into powder, then decoct one or two cups to consume. Chronic cases of dysentery should also use this.

    Another method: Use waxy tea; for red dysentery, decoct with honey water; for white dysentery, decoct with ginger juice and water; one or two doses will suffice.

    Yet another method: Use two qian of waxy tea, seven parts of soup, mix with one clam shell of sesame oil and consume. Soon, abdominal pain will stop and the thorough discharge will cease.

    Another method: Grind waxy tea, mix with white plum flesh to form pills; take one hundred pills down with licorice soup for red dysentery, and with black plum soup for white dysentery.

    Another method: Prepare tea with vinegar, take it hot; it will stop the disorder immediately.[198p]

    　　下痢禁口：沙糖半斤，乌梅一个，水二碗，煎一碗，时时饮之。 【《摘元方》】
    　　久痢禁口：石莲肉炒为末，每服二钱，陈仓米调下，便觉思食，甚妙。仍以日照东方壁土炒真橘皮为末，姜、枣略煎佐之。加入香连丸尤妙。【《丹溪心法》】
    　　下痢赤白：端午日午时取完好荸荠洗净拭干，勿令损破，放瓶内，入好烧酒浸之，黄泥密封收贮。遇有患者，取二枚细嚼，空心用原酒送下。【《经验方》】
    　　血痢泻血：乌药烧存性研，陈米饭丸梧子大，每米饮下三十丸。 【《普济方》】
    　　血痢不止：苦参炒焦为末，水丸梧子大，每服十五丸，米饮下。 【《仁存堂方》】[199p]

    For diarrhea, avoid solid food: take half a pound of sugar, one black plum, and two bowls of water, simmer down to one bowl, and drink it periodically.

    For chronic diarrhea, avoid solid food: grind stone lotus meat into powder, take two qian each time, mix with aged warehouse rice and swallow it, which will induce appetite—very effective. You can also fry the sun-exposed soil from the eastern wall into true orange peel powder, lightly simmer with ginger and dates as a supplement. Adding fragrant lotus pills is particularly effective.

    For diarrhea with red and white discharge: on the day of the Dragon Boat Festival, at noon, take perfect water chestnuts, wash them clean and dry them without damage, place them in a bottle and soak them in good liquor, sealing it tightly with yellow clay. When there are patients, take two pieces and chew them finely, swallowing with the original liquor on an empty stomach.

    For bloody diarrhea with bleeding: burn sichuan pepper to preserve its properties, grind it into powder, and form pills the size of walnuts; take thirty pills with rice wine.

    For persistent bloody diarrhea: roast bitter bolt to a charred state and grind it into powder, make water pills the size of walnuts, take fifteen pills with rice wine.[199p]

    　　休息痢疾，日夜无度，腥臭不可近，脐腹疼痛：用椿根白皮、诃黎勒各半两，母丁香三十个为末，酢糊丸梧子大，每服五十丸，米饮下。　　又方：用椿根白皮东南行者，长流水内漂三日，去黄皮焙为末，每一两加木香二钱，粳米饭为丸，每服一钱二分，空腹米饮下。
    　　水谷下痢，及每至立秋前后，即患痢兼腰痛：取樗根一大握，捣筛，以好面捻作馄饨如皂子大，煮熟，每日空心服十枚，并无禁忌，神效。【《传信方》】
    　　下利清血，腹中刺痛：椿根白皮洗刮晒研，酢糊丸梧子大，每空心米饮下三四十丸。一方加苍朮、枳壳减半。【《经验方》】
    　　血痢不止：薄荷叶煎汤常服。 【《普济方》】
    　　诸痢久下：艾叶、陈皮等分煎汤服之；亦可为末，酒煮烂饭和丸，每盐汤下二三十丸。【《圣济总录》】
    　　久痢休息，时止时作：鼠尾草花捣末，饮服一钱。 【《圣惠方》】[200p]

    1. For the relief of dysentery: if there are unrestrained episodes day and night, with a foul odor, and abdominal pain near the navel, use half a tael each of the white bark of the Chinese toon root and the fruit of the haritaki, along with thirty pieces of mother clove, ground into powder. Form into pills the size of a walnut, taking fifty pills each time, with rice drink.

    2. Another formulation: use white bark of Chinese toon root from the southeast, floating in clear water for three days, remove the yellow skin, roast and grind to powder. For each tael, add two qian of aromatic wood, mix with glutinous rice to form pills, taking twelve qian on an empty stomach with rice drink.

    3. For diarrhea with watery stools, especially around the beginning of autumn, accompanied by lower back pain: take a large handful of tree-of-heaven root, pound and sift, mold into dumplings the size of a soap bar, and cook until soft. Consume ten dumplings each day on an empty stomach, with no dietary restrictions, for remarkable effectiveness.

    4. For clear blood diarrhea with piercing abdominal pain: wash and scrape the white bark of the Chinese toon root and grind it. Form into pills the size of a walnut; take thirty to forty pills with rice drink on an empty stomach. Another method adds half the amount of fragrant wormwood and bitter orange peel.

    5. For persistent blood dysentery: brew peppermint leaves and consume the soup regularly.

    6. For chronic dysentery: equal parts mugwort and dried tangerine peel, brew into soup and take; it can also be powdered and mixed with wine to cook rice into a paste, formed into pills, taking twenty to thirty pills with salt water.

    7. For intermittent chronic dysentery: ground sage flower powder, drink one qian.[200p]

    　　血痢下血：腊月日未出时，取背阴地北引樗根皮，东流水洗净，挂风处阴干为未，每二两，入寒食面一两，新汲水丸梧子大，阴干。每服三十丸，水煮滚倾出，温水送下。忌见日，则无效。名如神丸。【《普济方》】
    　　一切下痢，不拘丈夫、妇人、小儿：木香一块方圆一寸，黄连半两，二味用水半升同煎干、去黄连，薄切木香焙干为末，分作三服，第一服橘皮汤下，二服陈米饮下，三服甘草汤下。此乃李景纯所传。有一妇人久痢将死，梦中观音授此方，服之而愈也。【《孙兆秘宝方》】
    　　里急后重：不蛀皂角子米糠炒过，枳壳炒等分为末，饭丸梧子大，每米饮下三十丸。 【《普济方》】
    　　骤然冷痢，白冻欲死，不拘男妇：用五月五日采麻叶阴干为末，每服二钱，冷水调下。勿吃热物，令人闷倒。只吃冷物。小儿半钱。
    　　下痢禁口：肥皂荚一枚，以盐实其内，烧存性为末，以少许入白米粥内食之，即效。 【《乾坤生意》】[201p]

    Blood Dysentery with Blood: In the twelfth lunar month, when the sun has yet to rise, take the bark of the angle tree from a north-facing shady area. Wash it clean with east-running water, hang it in a windy place to dry for a time. For every two taels of this, mix in one tael of cold food flour, form into pills the size of a walnut, and let them dry in the shade. Take thirty pills each time, boil water to a rolling point, pour it out, and take with warm water. Avoid sunlight, as this will render it ineffective. Known as the Divine Pill.

    All diarrhea, regardless of whether it is a man, woman, or child: Take a piece of wood fragrance that is one inch square, and half a tael of berberine. Boil these two ingredients together with half a liter of water until it reduces, then remove the berberine. Thinly slice the wood fragrance and dry it to a powder. Divide into three doses: the first dose taken with tangerine peel soup, the second with aged rice drink, and the third with licorice soup. This method was passed down by Li Jingchun. There was a woman who suffered from chronic dysentery and was near death; in a dream, she received this recipe from Guanyin and after taking it, she recovered.

    Urgent and Heavy Bowels: Take unbroken soap pods and stir-fried rice bran, then mix them equally into a powder. Form into pills the size of a walnut and take thirty with rice drink.

    Sudden Cold Dysentery, Feeling Frozen to Death, regardless of gender: Use leaves of hemp harvested on the fifth day of the fifth month, shade-dried and ground into powder. Take two cents each time, mixing with cold water. Do not eat hot food, as it will cause faintness. Only eat cold food. For children, use half a cent.

    Dysentery with Dietary Restrictions: Take one soap pod, fill it with salt, burn it until it retains its form, then grind into powder. Mix a small amount into white rice porridge and consume it for immediate effect.[201p]

    　　血痢不止：没石子一两为末，饭丸小豆大，每食前米饮下三十丸。 【《普济方》】
    　　赤白下痢：鸡冠花煎酒服，赤用红，白用白。 【《集简方》】　　又方：苍耳草不拘多少洗净，用水煮烂，去滓入蜜，用武火熬成膏，每服一二匙，白汤下。【《医方摘元》】
    　　凡痢下应先白后赤，若先赤后白为肠蛊。牛膝二两，捣碎，以酒一升，渍一宿，每饮一两杯，日三服。【《肘后方》】
    　　下痢转白：诃子二个，一炮一生为末，沸汤调服。水痢加甘草末一钱。 【《普济方》】
    　　赤白下痢：诃子十二个，六生六煨，去核焙为末。赤痢，生甘草汤下；白痢，炙甘草汤下。不过再服。【《济急方》】
    　　热痢腹痛：胡黄连末，饭丸梧子大，每米汤下三十丸。 【《钩元》】
    　　积滞泄痢，腹痛里急：杏仁去皮尖，巴豆去皮心，各四十九个，同烧存性，研泥镕蜡和丸菉豆大，每服二三丸，煎大黄汤下，间日一服。一加百草霜三钱。【《宣明方》】[202p]

    • For persistent bloody dysentery: grind one tael of stone powder into fine dust, make pills the size of small beans, and take thirty pills with rice wine before meals. [“Pujifang”]

    • For red and white dysentery: brew celosia (cockscomb flower) with wine. Use red for red dysentery and white for white dysentery. [“Jijianfang”] Another remedy: take an unmeasured amount of tung tree leaves, wash clean, boil until soft, remove residue, and mix with honey, then reduce with a gentle flame into a paste. Take one or two spoonfuls with warm water. [“Yifang Zhuanyuan”]

    • Generally, in dysentery, the discharge is first white and then red; if it is first red then white, it indicates intestinal gu. Take two taels of niuxi (Achyranthes bidentata), smash into pieces, soak in one liter of wine overnight, and drink one to two cups three times a day. [“Zhouhoufang”]

    • For white dysentery: take two haozai (chebula fruits), one raw and one boiled, grind into powder, and mix with boiling water to take. For watery dysentery, add one qian of licorice powder. [“Pujifang”]

    • For red and white dysentery: take twelve haozai, six raw and six boiled, pit and roast them into powder. For red dysentery, take with raw licorice soup; for white dysentery, take with roasted licorice soup. Just one more dose is required. [“Jijufang”]

    • For hot dysentery with abdominal pain: take powdered hu huanglian (barberry) and make pills the size of a wuziz (a type of tree fruit), taking thirty pills with rice soup. [“Gouyuan”]

    • For accumulated stagnation leading to painful dysentery: take forty-nine peeled apricot kernels and forty-nine peeled wild mint seeds, burn them until completely dry, grind into mud, mix with wax, and form pills the size of a mung bean. Take two or three pills, cooked with da huang (rhubarb) soup once every other day, adding three qian of baisuan (a powdered herbal remedy). [“Xuanmingfang”][202p]

    　　气痢赤白：巴豆一两，去皮心熬研，以熟猪肝菉豆大，空心米饮下三四丸，量人用。 【《经验方》】
    　　赤白下痢，阴阳交滞，不问赤白：刘寄奴、乌梅、白姜等分，水煎服。赤加梅，白加姜。【《如宜方》】
    　　冷痢腹痛不能食者：肉豆蔻一两，去皮，酢和面裹煨捣末，每服一钱，粥饮调下。 【《圣惠方》】
    　　痢频脱肛，黑色坚硬：用巴豆壳烧灰，芭蕉自然汁煮，入(石卜)硝少许洗软，用真麻油点火滴于上，以枯矾、龙骨少许为末，糁肛头上，以芭蕉叶托入。
    　　老少瘴痢，日夜百余度者：取干楮叶三两，熬捣为末，每服方寸匕，乌梅汤下，日再服。取羊肉裹末，纳肛中，利出即止。【《南行方》】
    　　赤痢久下，累治不瘥：黄连一两，鸡子白和为饼，炙紫为末，以浆水三升，慢火煎成膏，每服半合，温米饮下。一方，只以鸡子白和丸服。【《胜金方》】[203p]

    Dysentery with red and white: One ounce of castor seed, peeled and pounded, mixed with the size of a cooked pig's liver, taken with three to four pills using hollow rice soup, according to the person's needs.

    For red and white dysentery with stagnation of yin and yang, regardless of red or white: Mix equal parts of Liu Ji Nu, black plum, and white ginger, decoct in water and take. For red, add plum; for white, add ginger.

    For cold dysentery with abdominal pain and inability to eat: One ounce of nutmeg, peeled, mixed with vinegar, wrapped in dough and steamed to pound into a powder, take one cent each time, mixed with congee.

    Frequent dysentery with prolapse and hard black stools: Use the ash of castor seed husks, boil with natural juice of banana, and wash with a small amount of saltpeter to soften; drip true hemp oil upon it, and sprinkle a small amount of dry alum and dragon bone powder on the anal area, using a banana leaf to support it.

    For chronic dysentery in both old and young, with fevers exceeding one hundred degrees both day and night: Take three ounces of dried paper mulberry leaves, cook and pound into powder, take a mouthful with black plum soup twice a day. Take mutton wrapped in the powder, and stop once relieved.

    For chronic dysentery that has not healed despite several treatments: One ounce of coptis, mix egg white into a paste, roast until purple and grind into powder; simmer with three liters of water over a slow fire until it becomes a paste, take half a cup each time with warm rice drink. Alternatively, just use egg white to form pills.[203p]

    　　顺气止痢：枳壳炒二两四钱，甘草六钱为末，每沸汤服二钱。 【《婴童百问》】

    　　下痢赤白：生鸡子一个，取白摊绵连纸上日干，折作四重，包肥乌梅十个，安熨斗中，以白炭烧存性，取出碗覆，冷定研末，入水银粉少许。大人分二服，小儿分三服，空心井水调下。如觉微利，不须再服。【《活人书》】

    　　赤白暴痢，如鹅鸭肝，痛不可忍者：用黄连、黄芩各一两，水二升，煎一升，分三次热服。【《经验方》】
    　　休息痢疾，经年不愈：取大虫骨炙黄焦，捣末，饮服方寸匕，日三，取效。 【张大仲方】[204p]

    • To stop diarrhea due to excess gas: fry 2 liang and 4 qian of bitter orange peel, and 6 qian of licorice into a fine powder, and take 2 qian with boiling water.
    • For bleeding diarrhea that does not stop: mix equal parts of huanglian (coptis), wumei (ume fruit flesh), and earth from under the stove into a fine powder, and take with lukewarm tea.
    • For diarrhea of five colors: burn hedgehog skin into ash and take 2 qian with wine.
    • For severe diarrhea in children: use 1 sheng of fresh sheep dung and 1 sheng of water, soak overnight, squeeze the juice and take it in one go, and eat only at noon. Those severely affected may take up to three doses.
    • For red and white diarrhea: take one raw chicken egg, remove the white and dry the yolk on paper in the sun, fold it four times, wrap it with 10 fatty black plums, place in an iron pot, and burn with white charcoal until preserved. Take it out, grind it finely, and mix with a small amount of mercury powder, dissolving in well water. Adults take in two doses, children in three doses on an empty stomach. If only a slight improvement is felt, no further doses are necessary.
    • For acute red and white diarrhea, similar to the liver of geese or ducks with unbearable pain: use 1 liang each of huanglian and huangqin, boil with 2 sheng of water until reduced to 1 sheng, and take hot in three doses.
    • For persistent diarrhea that does not heal over the years: take large worm bones, roast until yellow and charred, grind into powder, and take 1/10 of a spoon three times a day to see results.[204p]

    　　禁口痢疾：腊肉脯煨熟食之，妙。 【《李楼奇方》】
    　　治痢：黄连、茱萸炒过四两，木香面煨一两，粟米饭丸。钱仲阳香连丸，治小儿冷热痢，加煨熟诃子肉。又治小儿泻痢，加煨肉豆蔻。治小儿气虚泻痢腹痛，加白附子尖。河间治久痢，加龙骨。丹溪治禁口痢，加石莲肉。王氏治痢渴，加乌梅肉，以阿胶化和为丸。
    　　伤寒下痢不能食者：黄连一斤，乌梅二十枚去核，炙燥为末，蜡一棋子大，蜜一升，合煎，和丸梧子大，一服二十丸，日三服。　　又方：黄连二两，熟艾如鸭子大一团，水三升，煮取一升，顿服立止。 【《肘后方》】
    　　赤白痢下，令人下部疼重，故名重下，日夜数十行，脐腹绞痛。以黄连一斤，酒五升，煮取一升半，分再服，当止绞痛也。【《肘后方》】
    　　毒痢禁口：水蛙一个，并肠肚捣碎，瓦烘热，入麝香五分，作饼贴脐上，气通即能进食也。[205p]

    For the treatment of restricted intake due to dysentery: Cooked dried meat is excellent.

    For treating dysentery: Four ounces of dried Coptis and Evodia fried, one ounce of Saussurea prepared, mixed with millet rice into pills. Qian Zhongyang's fragrant Coptis pills treat children’s hot and cold dysentery, adding cooked Myrobalan fruit. Also treats children's diarrhea and dysentery by adding cooked nutmeg. For children with weak qi, diarrhea, and abdominal pain, add Aconite tips. For persistent dysentery, add dragon bone. For restricted intake dysentery, add stone lotus fruit. Wang's method for dysentery with thirst adds black plum fruit, mixed with donkey-hide gelatin into pills.

    For those with typhoid and dysentery who cannot eat: One pound of Coptis, twenty pitted black plums, roasted to a powder, a piece of wax the size of a chess piece, and one liter of honey, combine and decoct, then form into pills the size of a walnut; take twenty pills each time, three times a day.

    Another formula: Two ounces of Coptis, a ball of prepared mugwort the size of a duck, three liters of water, boil down to one liter, and take it all at once to stop cramping immediately.

    For red and white dysentery, which causes severe pain in the lower abdomen, hence the name "heavy diarrhea," with numerous bowel movements day and night, and cramping abdominal pain: Use one pound of Coptis, five liters of wine, boil down to one and a half liters, split into two doses to stop the cramping.

    For toxic dysentery with restricted intake: Take one water frog, mash it including the intestines, heat in a tile, add five grams of musk, make into a cake and apply to the navel; when the qi circulates, eating can commence.[205p]

    Red and white dysentery: Use one foot of licorice, roasted and broken apart. Soak in one and a half liters of thin rice water, decoct to eight parts and take immediately for effectiveness.

    Febrile dysentery: In cases of febrile disorder lasting eight to nine days or longer, with great thirst and signs of heat, the Sanjiao (three burners) may have sores and dysentery, or the mouth may open with eroded tongue, sores in the mouth, and confusion. Use this to eliminate toxic heat and stop dysentery: half a pound of dragon bone, boil in ten liters of water to reduce to four liters, and take five parts cooled from the bottom of the well, gradually increasing the dosage.

    For dysentery with restricted oral intake: Three coins each of ginseng and lotus seeds, with two cups of well water, decoct to one cup and sip carefully, or add ginger juice and three coins of roasted berberine.

    Chronic rectal prolapse: Apply powdered white dragon bone.

    For chronic red and white dysentery with no cold or heat, only prolonged symptoms: Use forty-nine pieces of berberine and seven pieces of salt plum, place in a new bottle and burn until smoke dissipates, then grind to a fine powder and take two coins with salted rice soup.

    For dysentery with restricted oral intake: Roast and grind chicken inner gold, and take with milk.

    For bloody dysentery that does not stop: Three sheets of white paper, wrap one spoonful of salt, burn until red and grind to powder, take in three doses with rice drink.

    For dysentery with abdominal pain: Two liang each of goat fat, ejiao (donkey-hide gelatin), and wax, with two sheng of millet, cook into porridge and eat.[206p]

    　　下痢里急：穿山甲、蛤粉等分，同炒研末，每服一钱，空心温酒下。 【《普济方》】

    　　赤白痢下：黄雀儿去肠肚皮毛，以巴豆仁一枚入肚内，瓶固济，烧存性，研末，以好酒煮黄蜡百沸，取蜡和丸梧子大，每服一二十丸。红痢，甘草汤下；白痢，干姜汤下。【《普济方》】

    　　下痢休息：杏仁去皮麸炒研，以猪肝一具，切片水洗血净，置净锅中，一重肝，一重杏仁，铺尽，以童便二升同煎干，放冷，任意食之。【《圣惠方》】[207p]

    For acute diarrhea: Mix pangolin and clam powder equally, fry and grind into a fine powder. Take 1 qian (approximately 3 grams) and swallow with warm wine on an empty stomach.

    For chronic diarrhea with severe illness: Use one gold-threaded carp weighing 1-2 jin (approximately 500-1000 grams), clean it as usual, and add salt, sauce, and scallions, then incorporate 3-4 qian of ground pepper. Cook it thoroughly and have the patient smell it. If they want to eat, they can do so freely, and consume the broth until full; this will eliminate the illness permanently and is proven effective when used repeatedly.

    For red and white dysentery: Remove the intestines and skin from yellow sparrow, place one bean of croton in the abdomen, seal with a string, and roast until done. Grind into a fine powder and boil with good wine until the wax is thoroughly dissolved. Form into pills about the size of a chestnut. For red dysentery, take with licorice decoction; for white dysentery, take with dried ginger decoction.

    For blood in diarrhea: Combine a hundred herbs, sumac, and dried sophora flowers in equal parts, roast and grind into a fine powder. Mix with wine to form pills the size of a chestnut. Take 50 pills with rice drink.

    For diarrhea with prolapsed rectum: Boil one piece of a hundred herbs, three dried white plums, and a handful of papaya in one bowl of water, reducing to half a bowl, and take twice daily.

    For diarrhea requiring rest: Remove the skin from apricot kernels, fry and grind. Take one pig liver, slice and wash to remove blood, place in a clean pot. Layer liver and apricot kernels, then pour in two sheng (approximately 400-500 ml) of child’s urine and boil down until dry. Let cool and consume as desired.[207p]

    　　一切积痢：硇砂、朱砂各二钱半为末，用黄豆半两，巴豆仁三七粒，去膜，同入磁器内，重汤煮一伏时候，豆紫色为度，去二七粒，只将豆七粒，同二砂研匀，镕蜡和收，旋丸菉豆大，或三丸或五丸，淡姜汤送下。【《本事方》】
    　　赤痢血痢：山漆三钱研末，米泔水调服即愈

    Chronic dysentery with red and white discharge: Take a round of horse manure, burn it to ash, and drink with water.

    　　休息痢疾：五十以上一二年不瘥，变成疳下如泔淀者，用生羊肝一具切丝，入三年酢中吞之，心闷则止，不闷更服。一日勿食物。或以姜薤同食亦可，不过二三具。【《外台》】
    　　湿(上匿下虫)下痢不止，干呕羸瘦，多睡面赤：以胆汁和姜汁、酽酢同灌下部，捻令酢气上至咽喉乃止，当下五色恶物及虫而愈也。【《拾遗》】

    For Resting Dysentery: If one suffers from this condition for one or two years after the age of fifty, resulting in dysentery that resembles thin rice porridge, take a fresh sheep's liver, cut it into thin strips, and swallow it in three-year-old vinegar.     　　气痢不止：寒食一百五日，采木蓼暴干，用时为末，粥饮服一钱。 【《圣惠方》】

    • For persistent dysentery: After fasting for 105 days, harvest and dry the wood plantain, grind it into powder, and take one gram with porridge.

    　　治久冷痢下纯白者：由积卧冷处，经久病发，遂令脾胃俱冷，日夜五六十行，大小腹痛不可忍。凡白痢属冷，赤痢属热。皆宜好曲末五升，微熬令香，温清醇酒令热，和曲末一升，空心顿服之，日三服。若至食时，捣蒜一升令至熟，下姜椒末调和，如常食之。法惟须稠，勿加盐。以水和曲二升作(食素)饼，极烂煮之干，漉热，内蒜虀臼中相和，一顿食之。少与余食，至饥时仍准前食曲末酒，比至瘥来，少食余食，以此法治，不过两日，无有不瘥。[211p]

    Diarrhea with abdominal pain: Slice one dog liver, add one sheng of rice to cook porridge, and mix with five-flavored food.

    Severe dysentery: One sheng of fresh cow dung, one sheng of water, mix and strain the juice to drink, no more than three doses.

    For chronic cold dysentery with pure white stools: Caused by prolonged exposure to cold, leading to coldness in both spleen and stomach, resulting in fifty or sixty bowel movements a day, with unbearable pain in the lower and upper abdomen. White dysentery belongs to cold, red dysentery to heat. It is recommended to use five sheng of good fermented rice, lightly roasted until fragrant, mixed with warm clear strong wine to heat, and one sheng of fermented powder taken on an empty stomach, three times a day. When it’s time to eat, mash one sheng of garlic until cooked, add ginger and pepper powder, and mix as usual. The substance must be thick, without adding salt. Mix two sheng of water with the fermented rice to make (vegan) cakes, cook thoroughly, strain hot, mix in the garlic in a mortar, and eat it all at once. Give little leftover food, and when hungry, continue as before with the rice and wine. This method will cure in no more than two days, without exception.[211p]

    　　久冷或痢不痢间，但腹腰患苦冷：用上等新蜀椒三升，用酢宿渍之，以曲三升，和椒一升，紧拌煮作粥，空腹顿服之，加葱豉盐，任性调和，不瘥更作，以瘥为限，不过三升椒即愈。此方不但治冷，大治诸虚损冷，极有所益，久当自知耳。
    　　赤白下痢：腊月猪胆一百枚，每枚入雄黑豆充满，麝香少许，每服一枚，赤以甘草、白以干姜汤送下。【《奇效良方》】

    　　酒痢便血腹痛，或如鱼脑五色者：干丝瓜一枚，连皮烧研，空心酒服二钱。一方煨食之。【《经验良方》】[212p]

    For persistent cold or intermittent diarrhea, but with painful cold in the abdomen and lower back: Use three sheng of top-grade new Sichuan pepper, soak in vinegar overnight, mix with three sheng of wheat, and one sheng of pepper, stir tightly and cook into porridge.     　　赤白下痢：用酢榴根东生者一握炙干，水二大盏，浓煎一盏，空心服之。
    　　大热毒，纯血痢不可瘥者：黄连六两，(口父)咀，以水七升，煮取二升半，夜露着星月下。旦起，空腹顿服之，卧将息即止。不瘥，加黄芩二两，更作服之。仍不瘥者，以疳痢法治之。
    　　赤白滞下：清酒五合，成煎猪膏三合，缓火煎十沸，适寒温，顿服之，取瘥止。　　又方：酒四升，煮钱四十文，取二升，分二服。　　又方：乱发鸡子大，烧末水服，不过三服。
    　　治疳蚀痢：大麻子、胡麻各一升半，二物并熬令黄，以三升瓦瓶泥表止厚一寸，待泥干，内大麻等令满，以四五枚苇管插口中，密泥之，掘地作灶，倒立灶口，底着瓦器承之，密填灶孔中，平地聚炭，瓶四面着堑垒之，日没，放火烧，至明旦开取，适寒温，灌疳蚀者下部中一合，寻觉咽中有药气者为佳。亦不得过多，多则伤人。隔日一灌，重日再三灌之，从旦灌至夕。极觉体中乏力，勿怪也。[213p]

    Red and White Diarrhea: Take one handful of the root of the sour pomegranate from Dongsheng, dry it by roasting, extract with two large cups of water, and boil down to one cup. Take on an empty stomach.

    Severe Heat Toxicity, Pure Blood Dysentery: For those who can't recover, take six taels of Huang Lian (Coptis chinensis), chew it, and boil with seven liters of water to obtain two and a half liters.     Red and White Stagnant Diarrhea: Take five cups of clear wine, three cups of cooked pig fat, simmer gently until it has boiled ten times. Adjust to a suitable temperature and take it in one dose to stop the ailment.

    Treatment of Thinning and Eating Dysentery: Take one and a half liters each of great hemp seeds and sesame seeds, cook both until they turn yellow. Use a three-liter clay bottle, plaster the outer surface to a thickness of one inch and wait for it to dry. Fill the bottle with the seeds and insert four or five reed tubes into the mouth, sealing it tightly with clay. Dig a pit to make a stove, invert the stove opening, place a pottery vessel beneath it to catch the contents, and tightly fill the stove hole. Lay charcoal evenly on the ground surrounding the bottle. At sunset, light the fire and wait until morning to open and extract it; adjust to a suitable temperature. Administer one cup to those suffering from thinning dysentery and notice if there is a medicinal scent in the throat, which is a good sign. Do not take too much, as it can be harmful. Administer once every other day, and up to three times on consecutive days, from morning until evening. It’s normal to feel weak in the body; do not be alarmed.[213p]

    　　赤白下痢：用干姜、好墨各五两为末，酢浆和丸梧子大，每服三四十丸，米饮下，日夜六七服愈。【《肘后方》】
    　　一切痢下初起：百草霜三钱，金墨一钱，半夏七分，巴豆煮十四粒，研匀，黄蜡三钱，同香油化开，和成剂量大小，每服三五丸，或四五十丸，姜汤下。一服如神，名铁刷丸。【《潜江方》】
    　　休息下痢，经一二年不瘥，羸瘦衰弱：砒霜成块者为末，黄丹，各半两，化蜡入砒，以柳条搅焦则换，至七条取起收之，旋丸梧子大，冷水送下，小儿黍米大。【《局方》】
    　　血痢不止：蛇含石二枚，火煅酢焠研末，每服二钱，米饮下。 【《普济方》】
    　　久痢成疳者：胡粉和水及鸡子白服，以粪黑为度，为其杀虫而止痢也。
    　　下痢肛痛不可忍者：熬盐包坐熨之。 【《肘后方》，下同】
    　　赤白痢下，频数肠痛：官粉一两，鸡子清和炙焦为末，冷泉服一钱。[215p]

    Red and White Diarrhea: Use five taels each of dried ginger and good ink, grind into powder, mix with vinegar to form pills the size of a nut. Take three to forty pills with rice drink, six to seven times a day to recover. 【From "Zhouhou Fang"】

    Initial Stage of All Types of Diarrhea: Three qian of herbal frost, one qian of gold ink, seven fen of half summer, fourteen boiled beans, grind together, three qian of yellow wax, dissolve with fragrant oil, shape into doses. Take three to five pills, or forty to fifty pills, with ginger soup. One dose works wonders; named Iron Brush Pill. 【From "Qianjiang Fang"】

    Chronic Diarrhea lasting one to two years, causing weakness and emaciation: Use arsenic in blocks, half a tael of yellow lead, mix wax with arsenic, stir over burnt willow twigs until changed, then take seven twigs and shape into pills the size of nuts, taken with cold water, for children the size of millet. 【From "Ju Fang"】

    Unceasing Bloody Diarrhea: Two pieces of snake-shaped stones, calcine with fire and grind to powder, take two qian with rice drink. 【From "Pujifang"】

    Chronic Diarrhea Leading to Ulcers: Mix powder with water and egg white to take, using black feces as standard, to kill parasites and stop the diarrhea.

    Severe Anal Pain from Diarrhea: Boil salt in a bag and apply it to sit on. 【From "Zhouhou Fang," same as above】

    Red and White Diarrhea with Frequent Abdominal Pain: One tael of official powder, egg white mixed and slightly scorched into powder, take one qian with cold spring water.[215p]

    　　赤白痢下：用黄丹炒紫、黄连炒等分为末，以糊丸麻子大，每服五十丸，生姜甘草汤下。【《摘元方》】
    　　赤白下痢：密陀僧三两，烧黄色研粉，每服一钱，酢茶下，日三服。 【《圣惠方》】
    　　赤白久痢，积年不愈，调云母粉方寸匕服，二服立见神效。 【《千金方》】
    　　血痢腹痛：腻粉五钱，定粉三钱，同研水浸，蒸饼心少许，和丸菉豆大，每服七丸或十丸，艾一枚，水一盏，煎汤下。【《秘宝方》】
    　　　　针灸

    　　《甲乙经》曰：暴病头痛，身热痛，肌肉动，耳聋恶风，目眦烂赤，项不可以顾，髀枢痛泄，肠澼，束骨主之。　　肠澼泄切痛，四满主之。
    　　便脓血，寒中，食不化，腹中痛，腹哀主之。　　溏瘕，腹中痛，脏痹，地机主之。
    　　肠澼，中郄主之。
    　　病注下血，取曲泉、五里。肠中有寒，泄注肠澼，便血，会阳主之。　　肠鸣澼泄，下髎主之。[216p]

    For red and white dysentery: Grind equal parts of yellow lead and fried Coptis into a powder, shape into pills the size of sesame seeds, and take fifty pills with a decoction of ginger and licorice.

    For red and white dysentery: Use three taels of Myrobalan (密陀僧), burn it to yellow, and grind into powder. Take one qian (a measure) with vinegar tea, three times a day.

    For chronic red and white dysentery that has persisted for years: Take a mouthful of powdered muscovite, and after two doses, immediate efficacy will be seen.

    For bloody dysentery with abdominal pain: Take five qian of greasy powder and three qian of fixed powder, grind and soak in water; steam a little dough and mix into pills the size of mung beans. Take seven or ten pills with an egg and one cup of water, decoct and consume.

    Acupuncture

    The "Jia Yi Classic" states: For sudden illness with headache, body heat, muscle ache, deafness to wind, red and tearing eyes, an inability to look sideways, pain in the hip joint, and loose intestines, treat with the governing spine. For intestinal pain and loose bowels, treat accordingly.

    For pus in stool, internal cold, undigested food, and abdominal pain, treatment is at the Compassionate Yin point. For diarrhea and abdominal pain with visceral obstruction, treatment is at the Earth Mechanism point.

    For intestinal issues, treat at the Middle Valley point. For bloody stools with underlying cold, treat at the Ququan and Wuli points. If there is internal cold causing bloody diarrhea, treat at the Meeting Yang point. For gurgling intestines and loose stools, treat at the Lower Yin point.[216p]

    　　《千金方》曰：治肠中雷鸣，相逐痢下，灸承满五十壮。穴在侠巨阙两旁各二寸半。巨阙在心下一寸。　　泄注五痢，便脓血，重下腹痛，灸小肠腧百壮。　　泄痢不嗜食，虽食不消，灸长谷五十壮，三报。穴在侠脐相去五寸。　　泄痢赤白，灸足太阴五十壮，三报。　　久泄痢，百治不瘥，灸足阳明下一寸高骨上陷中，去大指岐三寸，随年壮。　　又法：屈竹[竹：原作「下」，据《千金》卷十五热痢改。]量正当两胯脊上点讫；下量一寸，点两旁各一寸；复下量一寸当脊上。合三处。一灸三十壮，灸百壮以上。一切痢皆断。亦治湿(上匿下虫)冷痢，脊上当胯点处不灸。又灸脐中，稍稍二三百壮。又灸关元三百壮，十日灸，并治冷痢腹痛，在脐下三寸也。　　赤白下，灸穷骨，惟多为佳。
    　　交信，主泄痢赤白漏血。
    　　复留，主肠澼，便脓血，泄痢后重，腹痛如痓状。　　小肠腧，主泄痢脓血，五色重下，肿痛。　　束骨，主肠澼泄。[217p]

    The "Thousand Gold Prescriptions" states: For treating thunder rumbling in the intestines, accompanied by diarrhea, apply moxibustion at Chengman with fifty strong strokes. The point is located two and a half inches on either side of the Xiajuque. Xiajuque is located one inch below the heart.

    For diarrheal discharge of pus and blood, with severe pain in the lower abdomen, moxibustion at the small intestine point should be done with a hundred strong strokes.

    For diarrhea causing loss of appetite and inability to digest food, even when eating, moxibustion at Changgu should be done with fifty strong strokes and three reports. The point is five inches away from the navel.

    For diarrhea characterized by red and white, moxibustion at the foot Taiyin should be done with fifty strong strokes and three reports.

    For chronic diarrhea that does not heal despite numerous treatments, moxibustion should be done at the point one inch below the foot Yangming, in the hollow of the bone, three inches from the big toe, adjusted according to the patient’s strength.

    Another method: Bend a bamboo measure to the appropriate length on the spine above the hips; measure down one inch to mark on either side, and again measure down one inch on the spine. Moxibustion should be applied at these three points, thirty strong strokes for each, or more than a hundred strokes altogether. This treatment can halt all types of diarrhea. It also treats cold-type diarrhea (with hidden worms), but do not apply moxibustion on the spine at the points above the hips. Also, apply moxibustion on the navel with two to three hundred strong strokes. Additionally, moxibustion at Guanyuan should be done with three hundred strong strokes over ten days, which treats abdominal pain from cold-type diarrhea located three inches below the navel.

    For diarrhea with both red and white discharge, apply moxibustion at Qionggu, with a preference for more strokes.

    Jiaoxin is indicated for diarrhea with red and white leaking blood.
    Fuliu indicates intestinal purging, with pus and blood in defecation, heavy post-diarrhea and abdominal pain resembling cramps.
    XiaoChangshu is indicated for diarrhea featuring pus and blood in various colors, along with swelling and pain in the lower abdomen.
    Shugu is related to intestinal purging and diarrhea.[217p]

    　　太白，主腹胀，食不化，善呕泄，有脓血。　　太冲、曲泉，主溏泄痢注下血。
    　　赤白泄痢，灸小肠腧五十壮。
    　　《医学纲目》曰：滞下，独取足太阴一经。经云：脾足太阴之脉所生病者，瘕溏泄。视盛虚热寒陷下取之也。里急后重，合谷、外关。
    　　　　导引

    　　《保生秘要》曰：痢病导引法，撮紧谷道，交双足而立，并目存神，垂两拳而直，缩腹耸肩，用意上提力，吸连三无间，督气上升，泻痢止矣。　　运功先用归元聚气，以推大肠，曲行泻火，收回，复顾念脐，取静，候泻定，服气补之。　　又法：推开肺经，大肠九曲去；又升肾水，上洗肺经。　　禁口痢：推开心头至肾，想肾水升至顶门，滴下心头洗之，以复脐中，转周天法。　　伤暑痢疾：运水洗肺经，推下大肠九曲去，泻止后顾脐念之即愈。　　归元聚气诀：土者，圭元也。以一心敦养于土，六根皆归于元，心有所注，久久凝定，便觉真种常在，方可用意运行。[218p]

    Tai Bai (the planet Venus) is associated with abdominal distension, inability to digest food, tendency to vomit and have diarrhea, and also with pus and blood.

    Tai Chong and Qu Quan are associated with dysentery, especially with blood in the stool.

The scripture states: diseases arising from the Spleen Foot Taiyin Meridian manifest as masses, diarrhea, and dysentery. One should observe the symptoms of excess and deficiency, heat and cold, and treat accordingly. For urgency and heaviness, use He Gu and Wai Guan points.

    Guided Movements

    The "Secret Essentials for Health Preservation" states: for the treatment of dysentery through guided movements, clench the perineum, stand with feet together, concentrate your spirit with your gaze, hang down both fists straight, draw in your abdomen and raise your shoulders, using your mind to pull up your energy. Inhale, allowing three breaths without interruption, and direct the energy upwards to stop the diarrhea.

    First, circulate energy to gather and consolidate it before pushing it through the Large Intestine, allowing for the flow to release heat, then draw it back and focus on the navel, seeking tranquility and waiting for the diarrhea to stabilize, supplementing energy as needed.

    Another method is: push open the Lung Meridian, releasing through the nine bends of the Large Intestine; then rise with Kidney water to cleanse the Lung Meridian.

    For mouth-related dysentery: push from the heart to the kidneys, envisioning Kidney water rising to the crown of the head to cleanse the heart, restoring balance in the navel and practicing the circulation method.

    For summer heat-induced dysentery: circulate water to cleanse the Lung Meridian, then push through the nine bends of the Large Intestine; after stopping the diarrhea, focus on the navel for recovery.

    The method of gathering energy: the Earth represents the original essence. With a focused heart, nourish in the Earth, letting all senses return to the origin; concentrate the heart for a long time, and you will feel the true essence always present, at which point you may use your mind to circulate energy.[218p]

    行之之法，提意出上，斡旋造化，从左而右，先运脐轮，收而放，放而复收，以还本位，不离这个，念自归真矣。　　周天法：先立安土守中，得诀纯熟后，行周天流通一身，散彻四肢滞气。其法从前运于脐轮，由小而大，大而收小，依次而上至璇玑穴，向左臂打圈，而下至曲池经内关，溯掌心及指尖，圈出背外关，而上肘后肩井及大椎，而下运于尾闾，由下复上，过玉枕，逾昆仑泥丸面部，上鹊桥而降重楼，达胃口，过脐至玉柱，复气海行入右腿，历膝关，由鞋劳穴穿足背至指尖，转涌泉，踵后上运，过阴谷，通尾闾，又圈至顶门，如前下鹊桥，依次送左腿似右法而落涌泉，又升泥丸及璇玑穴右行，照左手转过肩背，贯昆仑而下摄元海，如此将周身经脉宣畅，徐徐回转，但意至而气自相随，是为有作之周天法，亦可与造化参。[219p]

    The method of practice involves raising the intent upwards, circulating within the processes of nature, moving from left to right. First, cultivate the dantian, gathering and releasing, releasing and then gathering again, returning to the original state. Do not stray from this, and the mind will return to the truth.

    As for the method of circulating the whole body: first establish stability and guard the center, and once the techniques are mastered, perform circulation throughout the body to disperse stagnant energy in the limbs. The practice begins with movement at the dantian, expanding from small to large and then back to small, ascending sequentially to the Xuanzhi point, circling around the left arm, and descending to the Quqi and Neiguan points, tracing the palm and fingertips, circling the back of the wrist, ascending to the elbow, shoulder well, and Dachui, then moving down to the tailbone, and returning upward, passing over the Yuzhen, surpassing the Kunlun, above the facial area, and descending the Magpie Bridge to reach the stomach, crossing the dantian to the Yuzhu, then circulating to the right leg, passing the knee, penetrating through the Xiaolao point to the top of the foot and to the fingertips, turning at the Yongquan, rising at the heel, passing over the Yingu, connecting to the tailbone, and circling to the crown of the head. Following the descent from the Magpie Bridge, similarly send energy down the left leg as done on the right, then ascending through the Niwan and Xuanzhi on the right side, illuminating the left hand, turning over the shoulder and back, channeling through Kunlun and then down to gather yuanqi. In this way, the meridians throughout the body will become unimpeded, slowly revolving. As the mind directs, the energy naturally follows. This is the method of circulating the whole body that can also interact with nature.[219p]

    　　　　医案

    　　《东垣十书》曰：癸卯冬，白枢判家一老汉，面尘脱色，神气特弱，病脱肛日久，服药未验，复下赤白脓痢，作里急后重，白多赤少，不任其苦以求治。予曰：此非肉食膏粱，必多蔬食或饮食不节，天气虽寒，衣盖犹薄，不禁而肠头脱下者，寒也。真气不禁，形质不收，乃血滑脱也。此乃寒滑气泄不固，故形质下脱也。用诃子皮散濇去其脱而除其滑，微酸之味，固气上收；以大热之剂，而除寒补阳；以补气之药，升阳益气而安。[220p]

    Medical Case

    According to the "Ten Books of Dongyuan": In the winter of the Gui-Mao year, in the Bai Shu household, there was an old man with a dusty face and a notably weak spirit. He had been suffering from a long-standing case of rectal prolapse, had not found relief from medicines, and was also experiencing both red and white purulent dysentery, accompanied by a feeling of urgency and heaviness in the abdomen; there was more white than red, and he could not endure the pain in search of a cure. I said: This is not due to meat and rich foods but rather from a diet high in vegetables or irregular eating habits. Though the weather is cold, his clothing remains thin; he is unable to resist and his intestines have fallen due to cold. The true qi cannot be retained, and the bodily form is not consolidated, resulting in the blood being loose and slipping. This is due to a failure of cold and slippery qi to hold firm, causing the bodily form to descend. I will use a medicinal powder made from the skin of the haritaki fruit to relieve his prolapse and eliminate the slippery condition; its slightly sour taste will help to consolidate and raise the qi. I will administer a strongly warming medicinal formula to dispel the cold and or restore yang; using qi-replenishing herbs will elevate yang, enhance qi, and provide stability.[220p]

    　　《局方发挥》曰：予从叔年逾五十，夏间患滞下，病腹微痛，所下褐色，后重频并，谷食大减，时有微热，察其脉皆弦而濇，似数而稍长，却喜不甚浮大，两手相等，视其神气大减。予曰：此非滞下，忧虑所致，心血亏，脾气弱耳。遂与参、朮为君，当归身、陈皮为臣，川芎炒、白芍药、茯苓为佐使。时暄热甚，加少黄连，与两日而安。
    　　梅长官年三十余，奉养厚者。夏秋间患滞下，腹大痛，有人教服单煮干姜，与一贴，痛定。少顷又作，又与又定。由是服干姜至三斤。八日后，予视之，左脉弦而稍大似数，右脉弦而稍大减亦似数，重取之似紧。余曰：此必醉饱后吃寒冷太过，当作虚寒治之。因其多服干姜，遂教四物汤去地黄，加人参、白朮、陈皮、酒红花、茯苓、桃仁煎，入生姜汁饮之，至一月而安。[221p]

    The text states: As I turned over fifty, I suffered from a blockage in the lower abdomen during the summer, experiencing mild pain in the belly and dark-colored excretions. There was frequent heaviness, a significant reduction in appetite, and occasional slight fever. Upon examining the pulse, it was found to be string-like and deficient, slightly rapid yet somewhat elongated, without being overly floating. Both hands had equal strength, and I observed a substantial decrease in vitality. I concluded that this was not merely a blockage but a result of worry, with heart blood deficiency and weak spleen qi. Therefore, I prescribed ginseng and atractylodes as the main ingredients, with angelica, tangerine peel as assistants, and fried ligusticum, white peony, and poria as adjuncts. Given the intense heat, I added a little coptis, and after two days, the patient was at ease.

    As for Chief Mei, over thirty years old and well-nurtured, he suffered blockage in the lower abdomen during the summer and autumn, experiencing significant pain. Someone advised him to take single-boiled dried ginger, which alleviated the pain temporarily. However, the pain recurred shortly thereafter, and again he took the ginger, which provided relief. Consequently, he consumed three pounds of dried ginger over time. After eight days, I examined him again; the left pulse was string-like and somewhat stronger, while the right pulse was string-like yet slightly weaker. The pulse felt tense upon further inspection. I suggested that he must have overeaten and consumed excessive cold substances, hence it should be treated as a deficiency of cold. Due to the excessive intake of dried ginger, I prescribed the Four Substances Decoction omitting rehmannia, adding ginseng, atractylodes, tangerine peel, wine-red flower, poria, and peach kernel, decocted with fresh ginger juice, and after a month, he was stable.[221p]

    　　金氏妇年近四十，秋初尚热，患滞下，腹但隐痛，夜重于昼，全不得睡，食亦稍减，口干不饮，已服治痢灵砂二贴矣。余视之，两手脉皆濇且不匀，神思倦甚，饮食全减，因与四物汤，倍加白朮为君，以陈皮佐之，与十数贴而安。
    　　浦江郑兄年近六十，奉养受用之人也。仲夏久患滞下，而又犯房劳。忽一晚，正走厕间，两手舒撒，两眼开而无光，尿自出，汗如雨，喉如拽锯，呼吸甚微，其脉大而无伦次，无部位，可畏之甚。余适在彼，急令煎人参膏，且与灸气海穴，艾炷如小指大，至十八壮，右手能动；又三壮，唇微动。参膏亦成，遂与一盏，至半夜后，尽三盏，眼能动；尽二斤，方能言而索粥。尽五斤而利止，十斤而安。[222p]

    The wife of the Jin family was nearly forty years old. In early autumn, it was still hot, and she suffered from a stagnation below, experiencing only dull abdominal pain, which was worse at night than during the day, preventing her from sleeping entirely. Her appetite had slightly decreased, and she felt dry in her mouth without thirst. She had already taken two doses of a remedy for dysentery. Upon examination, both of her pulses were weak and irregular, and she appeared very fatigued. Her food intake was significantly reduced, so I prescribed the Four Substance Decoction, increasing the amount of white atractylodes as the main ingredient, with dried tangerine peel as an aid, and after taking a dozen doses, she felt settled.

    Brother Zheng from Pujiang was nearly sixty years old and was a person cared for and receiving assistance. In the middle of summer, he had long suffered from stagnation below and also had overexerted himself in sexual activity. One evening, while going to the toilet, he suddenly relaxed, his eyes opened without light, he urinated involuntarily, sweated profusely, and felt as if his throat was being pulled and sawed, with very faint breathing; his pulse was large and erratic, showing no clear position, which was very alarming. I happened to be there and quickly ordered ginseng paste to be prepared, and also instructed to moxibustion at the Qihai point with moxa cones the size of a little finger—up to eighteen cones, he regained movement in his right hand; after three more cones, his lips began to move slightly. The ginseng paste was ready, and I gave him one cup. By midnight, after consuming three cups, he could move his eyes; after finishing two pounds, he was able to speak and asked for congee. After finishing five pounds, the diarrhea stopped, and with ten pounds, he felt at ease.[222p]

    　　《丹溪心法》曰：一老人年七十，面白，脉弦数，独胃脉沉滑，因饮白酒作痢，下血淡脓水，腹痛，小便不利，里急后重，参、朮为君，甘草、滑石、槟榔、木香、苍朮为佐，下保和丸二十五丸。第二日前证俱减，独小便不利，以益元散与之，安。
    　　赵立道年近五十，质弱而多怒，七月炎暑，大饥索饭，其家不能急具，因大怒。两日后，得滞下病，口渴，自以冷水调生蜜饮之，甚快，滞下亦渐缓，如此五七日。召余视，脉稍大不数，遂令止蜜水，渴时，且令以人参、白朮煎汤，调益元散与之，滞下亦渐收。七八日后，觉倦甚发呃，余知因下久而阴虚也，令其守前药。然滞下尚未止，又以炼蜜饮之。如此者三日，呃犹未止。众皆尤药之未当，当以姜、附饮之。余曰：补药无速效，附子非补阴者，服之必死。众曰：冷水饮多，得无寒乎？余曰：炎暑如此，饮凉非寒，勿多疑，待以数日，药力到当自止。又四日而呃止，滞下亦安。[223p]

    The "Danxi Heart Method" states: An elderly man, aged seventy, had a pale face, with thin, rapid pulses; only his stomach pulse was deep and slippery. After drinking white wine, he developed dysentery, passing blood with thin pus and had abdominal pain, with difficult urination and urgency.     Zhao Lidao, nearing fifty, had a weak constitution and frequently lost his temper. In July, during the intense heat of summer and amidst great hunger, his family could not quickly provide food, which led to a great anger. Two days later, he developed stagnation and had difficulty with bowel movements, feeling thirsty, so he mixed cold water with honey to drink, which provided relief, and the stagnation gradually eased over five to seven days. When I was called to examine him, the pulse was slightly stronger but not rapid. I ordered him to stop drinking honey water. When thirsty, I instructed him to drink a decoction of ginseng and white atractylodes, along with Yiyuan San, and the stagnation continued to improve.

    After seven to eight days, he felt very fatigued and began to belch; I knew this was due to prolonged diarrhea leading to Yin deficiency, so I instructed him to continue with the previous medication. However, the stagnation had not yet ceased, and he was still drinking honey. After three days, the belching had not stopped. Many attributed this to improper medication and suggested ginger and fuzi (prepared aconite) be added. I said, "Tonics do not have immediate effects; fuzi is not for nourishing Yin, and taking it could be fatal." They said, "He drank a lot of cold water—could that be the cause of the cold?" I replied, "In such intense heat, drinking something cool isn’t the same as being cold—do not doubt too much, wait a few days; when the medicine takes effect, it will naturally stop." After another four days, the belching ceased and the bowel issues were also resolved.[223p]

    　　陈择仁年近七十，厚味之人也。有久嗽病，而作止不常。新秋，患滞下，食大减，至五七日后呃作。召余视之，脉皆豁大，众以为难。余曰：形瘦者尚可为，以人参白朮汤下大补丸以补血，七日而安。
    　　余族叔形色俱实，痃疟，又患痢，自恃强健能食，绝无忌惮。一日，召余曰：却健而能食，但苦汗出耳，汝能止此汗否？余曰：痃疟非汗不能愈，可虑者，强健与能食耳。此非痢也。胃热善消，脾病不化食与积，势已甚矣。此时宜节择饮食以养胃气，省出入以避风寒，候汗透而安。叔曰：世俗谓无饱死痢疾，我今能食，何谓可虑？余曰：痢而能食者，知胃气未病也，故言不死，非请恣食不节择也。不从所言，恣口大嚼过多，又啖水果，如此者月余，后强求治，不可着手矣。淹淹又月而死。《内经》以骄不论于理，为不治之病，信哉！[224p]

    Chen Zeren was nearly seventy years old, a person of considerable substance. He had a lingering cough for a long time, which occasionally ceased. In early autumn, he suffered from a blockage in his lower abdomen, reducing his appetite significantly, leading to vomiting after five or seven days.     My paternal uncle, robust in both form and complexion, was suffering from intermittent fever and also dysentery. He relied on his strength and ability to eat, without any caution. One day, he called for me and said: I am healthy and able to eat, yet I have profuse sweating; can you stop this sweat? I replied: The intermittent fever is not the sweating that hinders recovery; what is concerning is your strength and ability to eat. This is not dysentery. Your stomach is hot and well-digested; the spleen is struggling with food residue, and the condition has become severe. At this time, it is wise to regulate your diet to nourish your stomach energy, minimizing exposure to wind and cold, and wait for the sweat to pass for stability.

    He said: People say that one cannot die from dysentery while still able to eat; since I can eat, what is there to worry about? I replied: If one can eat but has dysentery, it indicates that the stomach energy is not yet affected, hence the claim of not dying. It is not about overindulging in eating without selection. Ignoring my advice, he indulged in excessive eating and also consumed fruits. After a month of this, he sought treatment, but it was too late to intervene. After another month, he passed away.     　　周姓者，形色俱实，患痢，善食而易饥，大嚼不择者，五月矣。余责之曰：病中当调补自养，岂可恣味戕贼？遂教其只用熟萝卜吃粥，且少与调治，半月而安。
    　　《养疴漫笔》曰：孝宗尝患痢，众医不效，德寿忧之。过宫，偶见小药肆，遣中使询之曰：汝能治痢否？对曰：专科。遂宣之至，请问得病之由，语以食湖蟹多，故致此疾。遂令诊脉，曰：此冷痢也。其法用新采藕节细研，以热酒调服。如其法杵细，酒调数服即愈。德寿大喜，就以杵药金杵臼赐之，至今呼为金杵臼严防御家。[225p]

    The Zhou person was robust in both body and appearance but suffered from dysentery. He had a good appetite but was easily hungry, devouring food indiscriminately for five months.     In the "Notes on Nurturing Illness," it is recorded that Emperor Xiaozong once suffered from dysentery, and despite the ineffectiveness of many doctors, De Shou was worried about him. The messenger then brought him in to ask about the cause of the illness, and it was mentioned that he had eaten too many river crabs, leading to this ailment. He was then asked to check the pulse and diagnosed it as a type of cold dysentery.     　　《医学正传》曰：一人年将五十，夏秋间得痢疾月余，服药而少愈，秽积已尽，但不食，昼夜五六次入厕，兼脱肛不安又半月，诸药不效。予记袓传一方，用池塘中鳖一个，如法修事，多用生姜米作羹，入沙糖一小块，不用盐酱，熟煮吃一二碗，三日不登厕，大肠自此实，肛门亦收而不脱矣。夫此证盖因脾土受虚，致肺与大肠俱失化源之所滋养，故是大肠不行收令也，此母能令子虚耳。鳖乃介虫，属金而有土性，温能补脾肺，又况肺恶寒，先得芩连等寒凉之味已多，今用生姜之辛以补肺金，用沙糖之甘以补脾土，肺气既实，其大肠亦随而实，故得以行收令也。故其功效如是之验焉。[226p]

    In the "Correct Transmission of Medicine," it is stated: There was a man nearing fifty who suffered from dysentery for more than a month in summer and autumn. Although he took medicine, he improved only slightly; his bowel movements had stopped, yet he could not eat, going to the toilet five to six times a day and also experiencing discomfort from prolapsed rectum for another half month, with no remedy proving effective. I remembered a formula passed down from my ancestors, which involved using a turtle from a pond. Following the method, I prepared it mainly with fresh ginger and a small piece of rock sugar, avoiding salt and sauces. After cooking it thoroughly, he consumed one or two bowls. Within three days, he did not need to go to the toilet, and from then on, his large intestine was functional, and the rectum returned to normal. This condition was likely due to a deficiency in the spleen, leading to a lack of nourishment for both the lungs and the large intestine. Thus, the large intestine was unable to function properly. The turtle, categorized as a shellfish and having an element of earth, is warm and can nourish the spleen and lungs. Moreover, the lungs, having been exposed to cold due to previous treatments involving bitter and cold herbs, now required warming. Therefore, ginger, which is spicy, was used to restore the lung's metal element, and the sweetness of rock sugar was employed to fortify the spleen's earth element. Once the lung energy was sufficient, the large intestine also became robust, allowing it to regain its function. Hence, the effectiveness of this method was evident.[226p]

    　　先母年八十，仲夏患痢腹痛，作呕不食，热渴引汤，手按腹痛稍止，脉鼓指而有力，真气虚而邪气实也。急用人参五钱，白朮、茯苓各三钱，陈皮、升麻、附子、炙甘草各一钱服之。睡觉索食，脉证顿退，再剂而安，此取证不取脉也。凡暴病当从证不从脉。时石阁老太夫人，其年岁脉证皆同，彼专治其痢，遂致不起。

    　　《医宗必读》曰：屯院孙潇湘夫人下痢四十日，口干发热，不食，腹中胀闷，完谷不化，尚有谓其邪热不杀谷者。计服香、连、枳壳、豆蔻、厚朴等三十余剂，绝谷五日，命在须臾。迎余诊之，脉大而数，按之豁然，询得腹痛而喜手按，小便清利，此火衰不能生土，内真寒而外假热也。急煎附子理中汤，冰冷与服，一剂而痛止，六剂而热退食进。兼服八味丸二十余日，霍然起矣。
    　　淮安郡侯许同生令爱痢疾腹痛，脉微而软，此气虚不能运化精微，其窘迫后重者，乃下陷耳。用升阳散火汤一剂，继用补中益气汤十剂即愈。
    　　文学顾伟男之内，痢疾一月，诸药无功。余诊之曰：气血两虚，但当大补。痢家药品，一切停废。以十全大补连投十剂，兼进补中益气加姜、桂二十余剂而安。[232p]

    "The Essential Medical Texts" states: Lady Sun Xiaoxiang, who suffered from dysentery for forty days, experienced dry mouth, fever, lack of appetite, abdominal bloating, and undigested food. There were those who argued that the invading heat did not harm the food. She took over thirty prescriptions of Xiang, Lian, Zhi Ke, Dou Kou, and Hou Po, but after five days of fasting, her life was in danger. When I was called to diagnose her, her pulse was large and rapid; upon palpation, it was clear that her abdominal pain subsided with pressure, and her urination was clear and smooth. This indicated that the fire was weak and could not generate earth, showing true cold internally but false heat externally. I urgently prepared a decoction of Fu Zi and Li Zhong Tang and administered it cold, leading to the relief of pain after one dose, and after six doses, her fever subsided and she was able to eat. After taking Ba Wei Wan for over twenty days, she recovered remarkably.

    In Huaian County, the daughter of Lord Xu Tongsheng suffered from dysentery and abdominal pain, with a pulse that was weak and soft, indicative of qi deficiency unable to transform essence. Her urgency and heaviness were due to prolapse. I used Sheng Yang San Huo Tang for one dose, followed by ten doses of Bu Zhong Yi Qi Tang, which led to her recovery.

    In the case of Wenxue Gu Weinan, he had dysentery for a month, with all medicines proving ineffective. I diagnosed him with both qi and blood deficiency, proposing a heavy supplementation. All medications for dysentery were halted. I prescribed ten doses of Shi Quan Da Bu Tang and, alongside that, twenty doses of Bu Zhong Yi Qi added with ginger and cinnamon, achieving a state of calm.[232p]

    　　兵尊张絅庵秋间患痢，凡香、连、枳、朴等剂，用之两月而病不衰。余诊之，滑而有力，失下之故也。用香、连、归、芍、陈皮、枳壳，加大黄三钱，下秽物颇多。脉尚有力，仍用前方，因积滞如鱼肠者数碗。调理十余日而痊。
    　　抚台毛孺初痢如鱼脑，肠鸣切痛，闻食则呕，所服皆芩、连、木香、菖蒲、藿香、橘红、芍药而已。后有进四君子汤者，疑而未果。飞艇相招，兼夜而往。诊得脉虽洪大，按之无力，候至右尺，倍觉濡软。余曰：命门火衰，不能生土，极须参、附可以回阳。孺翁曰：但用参、朮，可得愈否？余曰：若无桂、附，虽进参朮，无益于病。且脾土大虚，虚则补母，非补火乎？遂用人参五钱，熟附一钱五分，炮姜一钱，白朮三钱，连进三剂，吐止食粥。再以补中益气，加姜附，十四剂后即能视事。[233p]

    During autumn, General Zhang Qing'an suffered from dysentery. He tried various remedies like Xiang, Lian, Zhi, and Pu for two months, but his condition did not improve. Upon examination, his pulse was slippery yet strong, indicating that he had lost his ability to expel. I used a combination of Xiang, Lian, Gui, Shao, Chenpi, and Zhihua, along with three qian of Dahuang, leading to a considerable expulsion of waste. His pulse remained strong, so I continued with the same prescription, considering the accumulation as substantial as fish intestines. After over ten days of treatment, he recovered.

    The official Mao Ru initially had dysentery that presented with severe abdominal pain and gurgling sounds, leading to vomiting upon the sight of food. He had only taken Qinshi, Lian, Muxiang, Changpu, Huoxiang, Juhong, and Shaoyao. Later, someone administered Si Jun Zi Tang, which I found dubious but didn’t pursue further. He called for me at night for a diagnosis. Although his pulse was full and large, it felt weak under pressure, especially at the right wrist, where it was particularly soft. I deduced that the fire at the life gate was weak and could not generate Earth, thus he urgently needed Ren and Fu to restore Yang. Ru said: “If I only use Ren and Shu, can he recover?” I replied: “Without Gui and Fu, even with Ren and Shu, it would not benefit the illness. Moreover, the Spleen Earth is greatly deficient; deficiency requires to supplement the Mother, does it not? Thus, I prescribed five qian of Ren, one and a half qian of Fu, one qian of Paojiang, and three qian of Baizhu, administering three doses, after which vomiting ceased and he could eat congee. Further, I added Bu Zhong Yi Qi with ginger and Fu; after fourteen doses, he was able to attend to matters again.[233p]

    　　《奇效良方》曰：唐太宗苦于气痢，诏问有能治其疾者，当重赏。有术士张宝藏进此方，时赏官三品。方用牛乳半升，荜茇末二钱匕，同煎减半，空心服。
    　　昔有人患痢，便下脓血，忽见水浸甜瓜，心酷喜之，连皮食数枚，脓血皆已。
    　　陈庆长子年十许岁，患禁口痢，水浆不入数日，惟能进药。一人用山药末米饮调服，一服而痢稍疏，三服遂思粥饮，顿食半盏许，自是痢止而安。[234p]

    The "Remarkable Remedies" states: Emperor Taizong of the Tang dynasty suffered from dysentery and issued an edict promising a heavy reward for anyone who could cure his illness. A practitioner named Zhang Baozang presented this remedy and was rewarded with a third-rank official position. The recipe includes half a liter of cow's milk and two qian of powdered ginger, boiled down by half and taken on an empty stomach.

    In the past, there was a person who suffered from dysentery, experiencing pus and blood in his stools. He suddenly saw sweet melons soaked in water and, filled with delight, ate several pieces with the skin, after which the pus and blood ceased.

    Chen Qing's eldest son, around ten years old, suffered from severe dysentery, unable to take water or grain for several days, only able to take medicine. A person used powdered yam mixed with rice water for him, and after one dose, the dysentery became slightly better; after three doses, he craved porridge and was able to consume about half a bowl, after which his dysentery stopped and he felt at ease.[234p]

    　　《医贯》曰：一孕妇疟痢齐发，医治两月余。疟止而痢愈甚，又加腹痛，饮食少进，延余视之。余曰：虚寒也。以补中益气，加姜、桂，一服痢止大半，再一服而反加疟病大作。主人惊恐，余曰：此吉兆也。向者疟之止，乃阴盛之极，阳不敢与之争，今服补阳之剂，阳气有权，敢与阴战，再能助阳之力，阴自退听。方中加附子五分，疟痢齐愈。大服补剂，越三月产一子，产后甚健。
    　　《寓意草》曰：朱孔阳年二十五岁，形体清瘦，素享安逸，夏月因构讼，奔走于日中，暑湿合内郁之火，而成痢疾。昼夜一二百次，不能起床，以粗纸铺于褥上，频频易置，但饮水而不能进食，其痛甚厉，肛门如火烙，扬手掷足，躁扰无奈。余诊其脉，弦紧劲急，不为指挠，谓曰：此证一团毒火，郁结在肠胃之内，其势如焚，救焚须在顷刻，若二三日外，肠胃朽腐矣。[235p]

    The "Medical Comprehensive Treatise" states: A pregnant woman experienced both malaria and dysentery simultaneously, and was treated for more than two months. The malaria subsided, but the dysentery worsened, accompanied by abdominal pain and reduced appetite, prompting me to examine her again. I said: This is a condition of deficiency and cold. I prescribed a restorative formula to boost the central qi, adding ginger and cinnamon. After one dose, the dysentery improved significantly; after a second dose, however, the malaria symptoms intensified alarmingly. The host was frightened, but I reassured them: This is a good sign. The prior cessation of malaria indicated an extreme dominance of yin, causing yang to refrain from confrontation. Now, with a tonic for yang, the yang energy is fortified enough to contend with yin, thus helping yang's strength and allowing yin to recede. I added five grams of prepared aconite to the prescription, and both malaria and dysentery were cured. After taking a large restorative dose, three months later she gave birth to a son, and she was very healthy after childbirth.

    The "Meaning in Herbs" states: Zhu Kongyang, aged twenty-five, was slender and accustomed to a life of leisure. During the summer months, due to involvement in a lawsuit, he was out during the hot midday, causing internal heat from the combined effects of heat and humidity, resulting in dysentery. He experienced frequent bowel movements, one to two hundred times a day, unable to get out of bed. He laid coarse paper on his bedding, replacing it frequently, only able to drink water but unable to eat, suffering intensely with rectal pain that felt like being burned. He would flail his limbs, restless and miserable. I examined his pulse, which was tight and forceful, refusing to yield under pressure. I remarked: This condition signifies a mass of toxic fire, trapped within the intestines and stomach, burning fiercely. Immediate rescue is necessary; if delayed by two or three days, the intestines and stomach will rot away.[235p]

    于是以大黄四两，黄连、甘草各二两，入大砂锅内煎，随滚随服，服下，人事稍宁片刻，少顷，仍前躁扰一昼夜，服至二十余碗，大黄俱已煎化，黄连、甘草俱煎至无汁。次日，病者再求前药。余诊毕，见脉势稍柔，知病可愈，但用急法，不用急药。遂改用生地黄、麦门冬各四两，另研生汁，而以天花粉、牡丹皮、赤芍药、甘草各一两，煎成和汁大碗咽之。以其来势暴烈，一身津液，从之奔竭，待下痢止，然后生津养血，则枯槁一时难回。今脉势既减，则火邪俱退，不治痢而痢自止，岂可泥润滞之药而不急用乎？服此药，果然下痢尽止，但遗些少气沫耳。第三日，思食豆腐浆。第四日，略进陈仓米清汁。缓缓调至旬余，方能消谷。亦见胃气之存留一线者，不可少此焦头烂额之客耳。[236p]

    Then, four taels of rhubarb, two taels each of coptis and licorice were put into a large sand pot for decoction, taken while boiling, and consumed. After taking the medicine, the person was somewhat calm for a moment, but shortly thereafter, the restlessness returned for a whole day and night. After taking more than twenty bowls, the rhubarb had completely dissolved, and the coptis and licorice were boiled down to dryness. The next day, the patient again requested the previous medicine. After the diagnosis, I saw the pulse was somewhat softer and knew the illness could be cured, but I opted for an urgent method instead of urgent medicine. Thus, I changed to four taels each of raw rehmannia and ophiopogon, and separately extracted their fresh juices. I then added one tael each of powdered trichosanthes, peony bark, red peony, and licorice, and decocted them into a large bowl of harmonious fluid to drink. Because the onset was fierce, all bodily fluids had been depleted, and one must wait for the diarrhea to stop before nourishing the blood and fluids, as recovering from such depletion would take time. Now that the pulse had softened, the fiery pathogen had retreated; if one did not treat the diarrhea, it would stop on its own. How could one rely on lubricating and stagnating medicines without urgent action? After taking this medicine, indeed the diarrhea ceased completely, leaving only a little residual froth. On the third day, the patient craved tofu soup. On the fourth day, I gradually introduced clear broth from old warehouse rice. Slowly adjusting over ten days, he was eventually able to digest grains. It was also noted that the presence of stomach qi must not overlook this urgent matter at hand.[236p]

    　　陈汝明病痢，发热如蒸，昏沉不食，重不可言。至第三日，危急将绝，方请余诊。其脉数大空虚，尺脉倍加洪盛，谓曰：此两病而凑于一时之证也。内有湿热与时令外热相合，欲成痢证，尚不自觉，又犯房劳，而为骤寒所乘，以故发热身重，不食昏沉，皆属少阴肾经外感。少阴受邪，原要下利清白，此因肠中湿热已蒸，成猪肝鱼脑败浊之形，故色虽变，而下利则同也。再用痢疾门药一剂，即刻不救矣。遂忙以麻黄附子细辛汤一剂与之，表散外邪，得汗后热即微减；再以附子理中汤，连进二剂，热退，身轻能食；改用黄连理中汤丸服，至旬日全安。[237p]

    Chen Ruming was suffering from dysentery, with fever as if steamed, heavy and unable to eat, feeling extremely unwell. On the third day, in critical condition, he requested my diagnosis. His pulse was rapid and considerably hollow, with the pulse at the wrist being especially strong. I said: This is a case where two illnesses coincide at one time. Internally, there is damp-heat combining with the external heat of the season, wanting to manifest as dysentery, yet he remained unaware, having also engaged in excessive sexual activity, which contributed to being suddenly attacked by cold. Hence, the fever, heaviness, and inability to eat are all related to the external invasion of the Lesser Yin Kidney channel. When the Lesser Yin is affected, one should expect diarrhea of clear fluids. This is because the damp-heat in the intestines has already boiled into a foul form resembling pig liver or fish brain; thus, although the color changes, the diarrhea remains the same. If I were to administer a remedy for dysentery at this point, it would be of no help. I hastily gave him a dose of Mahuang, Fuzhu, and Xixin Decoction to dispel the external pathogen, and after sweating, his heat slightly diminished. Then, I used Fuzhu Lizhong Decoction as well, giving two doses; the heat receded, and he felt lighter and was able to eat. I switched to taking Huanglian Lizhong Pills, and by the tenth day, he was completely well.[237p]

    　　叶茂卿幼男病痢禁口，发热十余日，呕哕连声不断，诊其关脉上涌而无根，再诊其足脉，亦上涌而无根。谓其父曰：此非禁口痢之证，乃胃气将绝之证也。禁口痢者，虚热在胃，壅遏不宣，故觉其饱而不思食，治宜补虚清热两法。此因苦寒之药所伤，不能容食，治惟有颛颛温补一法而已。于是以理中汤连投二剂，不一时，痢下十余行，遍地俱污。茂卿恐药不对证，求更方。余曰：吾意在先救胃气之绝，原不治痢。即治痢，人之大小肠盘迭腹中甚远，虽神丹不能遽变其粪，今借药力催之速下，正为美事，焉可疑之？遂与前药连服二日，人事大转，思食不哕，痢势亦减。四日后止便糟粕，以补中益气，调理旬日全安。此可见小儿之痢，纵啖伤胃者多，内有积热者少，尤不宜轻用痢疾门中通套治法也。[238p]

    Ye Maoqing, a young boy, suffered from dysentery and was instructed not to eat. He had a fever for more than ten days, with continuous vomiting. Upon examining his pulse, it was surging upward without a root; the pulse in his feet showed the same condition. I told his father: "This is not a case of dysentery caused by dietary restriction; rather, it is a sign that the stomach's qi is about to fail. In dysentery from dietary restriction, there is virtual heat in the stomach, stagnating and not dispersing, hence the sensation of fullness without appetite. The treatment should focus on nourishing deficiency and clearing heat. This condition arises from the harm of bitter and cold medicines, which cannot accept food; thus, warm nourishment is the only remedy."

    I then administered two doses of the "Li Zhong Tang" (Regulating the Center Decoction). In no time, he experienced ten or more bouts of dysentery, and the surroundings became messy. Maoqing feared that the medicine was inappropriate for his condition and requested a different prescription. I replied: "My aim is to first save the qi of the stomach from failing, and I am not treating the dysentery directly. Dysentery involves the large and small intestines, which are quite distant in the body; even a miraculous pill cannot instantly change the stool. Encouraging it to come out quickly with medicine is indeed a good thing—how could that be doubted?"

    So, I continued the previous medicine for another two days. His condition greatly improved; he began to feel hungry without vomiting, and the dysentery's intensity decreased. Four days later, he only passed damp remnants. After restoring the Qi with nourishing methods and regulating his condition for ten days, he fully recovered. This illustrates that in children with dysentery, even if they have consumed food that harms the stomach, it is rare to find accumulated heat inside. Thus, it is particularly inadvisable to lightly apply the standard methods for treating dysentery.[238p]

    　　浦君艺病痢疾，初起有表邪未散，而误用参、朮固表，使邪气深入，又误服黄连凉解，大黄推荡，治经月余，胃气不运，下利一昼夜百余行。一夕，呕出从前黄连药汁三五碗，呕至二三次后，胃与肠遂打为一家，内中幽门阑门洞开无阻，不但粥饮直出，即人参浓膏，才吞入喉，已汩汩从肠奔下。危急之中，诸昆玉及内戚俱探余曰：此证可无恐乎？余曰：在此用药，便有可恃，吾岂不知疾势之危？但无别人可任，姑以静镇之，而殚力以报知己耳。于是以大剂四君子汤，煎调赤石脂、禹余粮二末，连连与服，服后其下利之势少衰，但腹中痛不可忍。君艺曰：前此下痢虽多，然尚不痛，服此药而痛增，未可再服矣。余曰：此正所谓通则不痛，痛则不通之说也。不通则危，痛则安，何乐而不痛耶？仍以前药再进。俟势已大减，才用四君子倍茯苓十余剂全安。

    Mr. Pu Junyi fell ill with dysentery. At first, he had an outward pathogen that had not yet dispersed, but mistakenly used ginseng and atractylodes to strengthen the exterior, allowing the pathogenic qi to penetrate deeply. He also mistakenly took huanglian to cool and resolve heat, and da huang to purge, which he did for more than a month, resulting in his stomach qi being out of order, with over a hundred watery stools in one day. One evening, he vomited three to five bowls of the yellow lotus medicine, and after vomiting two or three times, his stomach and intestines seemed to become one. The pylorus and the lower orifice were wide open without obstruction; not only did the congee and drink flow straight out, but even ginseng extract, once swallowed, rushed down immediately from the intestines. In this critical situation, various friends and relatives asked me: "Is there no fear in this condition?" I replied, "With the medicine I’m using, there is something to rely on. Am I unaware of the severity of this illness? But there is no one else to depend on; I will temporarily calm him down while doing my best to inform his supporters." Thus, I prescribed a large dose of the Four Gentlemen Decoction, decocted with powdered red stone fat and Yu Yu grain, and continuously administered it. After taking it, the rate of diarrhea diminished slightly, but he experienced unbearable abdominal pain. Junyi said: "Although I had much diarrhea before, there was no pain. After taking this medicine, the pain increased; it cannot be taken again." I replied: "This is precisely the saying that when it flows, there is no pain; when there is pain, it does not flow. If it does not flow, it is dangerous; if it hurts, it is safe. Why would one not prefer to feel pain?" I continued with the previous medicine. Once the condition improved significantly, I then used an increased amount of the Four Gentlemen Decoction with more than ten doses of poria to ensure complete safety.[239p]
